Laudes x Dark Matter Labs: A just transition of Europe’s built environment was originally published in Dark Matter Laboratories on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

13:47 • 9 days ago

Trinsic Blog

Trinsic Releases IDtech Product Market Map

People often ask us: What are examples of IDtech products? Normally, we end up sharing a list on Twitter or a few screenshot examples on a call. We figured it was time to more formally share our perspective on the top IDtech products in the market. And so, we created the IDtech Product Market Map […] The post Trinsic Releases IDtech Product Market Map appeared first on Trinsic.

People often ask us: What are examples of IDtech products? Normally, we end up sharing a list on Twitter or a few screenshot examples on a call. We figured it was time to more formally share our perspective on the top IDtech products in the market. And so, we created the IDtech Product Market Map as an attempt to showcase some of the most compelling and successful IDtech applications to date.

Click to download PDF What is an IDtech product?

Trinsic has written extensively on IDtech products and their importance to the future of identity. In this post, we include a brief explanation, but if you would like to dive further, check out our blog posts.

 

When we talk about IDtech products, we’re talking about applications that empower users to take control of their identity, share their data safely, and more securely access the things they need. These products aren’t necessarily decentralized, though we believe decentralized identity solutions will eventually win because they are better for users.

 

We’ve purposefully not included infrastructure platforms (you’ll note that Trinsic is not on the map), open source libraries, or blockchains on this list. While these things enable the creation of IDtech companies and their products, they are not categorized as IDtech in and of themselves. The reason being is that IDtech refers specifically to products and applications that help consumers manage their identity and data.

What are the top IDtech products right now?

The IDtech Product Market Map features IDtech products in 9 different sectors of the market, including:

Consumer Dentity DEPASS GetOutPass MySudo UNiDAYS Education Accredify BenchK12 Digitary Learning Economy RANDA Finance ASA Bonifii Domi Oliu Portabl Verimi Government ID.me itsme® Merit Sora UltraPass Unum ID Yoti Healthcare Axuall Bindle HPEC Patchwork Truu ZADA Supply Chain Bluenumber farmer connect Spherity Transmute Travel Airside CLEAR One37 Web3 Crucible Disco Gitcoin Passport Liquid Avatar Nuvo REHUMAN Workforce Cerebrum CySecure Entidad JNCTN SmartResume Talentpair 10ure

There is a chance we may have missed an amazing IDtech product that is out there. If that is the case, let us know. We plan on updating the IDtech Product Market Map as new key players emerge.

Why the focus on IDtech products?

IDtech products are opening a new world of digital experiences for both people and businesses. We believe IDtech is on the verge of breakthrough growth that will be compared to the Fintech boom that brought the means for businesses, both large and small, to provide financial services directly to customers like never before.

 

Of course, Trinsic is an IDtech infrastructure company. IDtech companies build on top of Trinsic, so they can spend the majority of their time focused on bringing their product to market instead of building complex, underlying infrastructure. We have chosen to build our infrastructure with decentralized technologies, because as we mentioned above, we feel that decentralized identity (often called SSI) provides the most optimal experience for end users to date.

 

The number one factor that will influence the adoption of decentralized identity is amazing IDtech products that users love. IDtech products that solve real problems for users. We are excited to see the continued success of the IDtech products listed in the market map and look forward to the development of many more!

The post Trinsic Releases IDtech Product Market Map appeared first on Trinsic.

11:40 • 9 days ago

Ayan Works

AyanWorks won ‘FIDO Developer Challenge 2022 — India: Go Passwordless with FIDO Authentication’

AyanWorks won “FIDO Developer Challenge 2022 - India: Go Passwordless with FIDO Authentication” We at AyanWorks, have always been moved by challenging ourselves with the complex problems in the Blockchain space, be it exploring & evaluating new stacks, contributing to complex open source projects, taking challenges head on to build solutions for, participating in the hackathons to build solut
AyanWorks won “FIDO Developer Challenge 2022 - India: Go Passwordless with FIDO Authentication”

We at AyanWorks, have always been moved by challenging ourselves with the complex problems in the Blockchain space, be it exploring & evaluating new stacks, contributing to complex open source projects, taking challenges head on to build solutions for, participating in the hackathons to build solutions with cutting edge technologies. Continuing with this DNA, AyanWorks team participated in the ‘FIDO Developer Challenge 2022 — India’ hackathon event. Theme for this challenge was ‘Go Passwordless with FIDO Authentication’. More details can be found here.

We are thrilled to announce that AyanWorks has made it to the top 3 finalists in the challenge. We are honoured to be recognised for our innovative work in the field of digital identity and verifiable credential management (see official announcement from FIDO Alliance).

Demo Day

The final demo and awards event was held at the Samsung Research Institute in Noida and it provided us with a fantastic opportunity to meet and network with various individuals and developers in the field. It was an great platform for us to showcase our SSI (Self-Sovereign Identity) mobile wallet app, powered by FIDO Passkeys, which stores user’s credentials securely using advanced cryptography, thus preserving the privacy of the individual and the data in her wallet. As they call — ‘Privacy-by-Design’ and ‘Privacy-by-Default’.

Our team worked tirelessly to develop the solution that is not only secure but also user-friendly and easy to use, making it accessible to everyone. We believe that digital decentralised identity and cryptographically signed & digitally verifiable credential management is an important step towards a more secure and reliable internet ecosystem. Our SSI mobile wallet app, implements the authentication method using FIDO Passkeys, provides a solution to some of the most significant challenges faced in the space today, such as security vulnerabilities and data breaches.

At AyanWorks, our primary focus has always been on creating innovative solutions that serve the best interests of our clients and users. That’s why we’re proud to say that our SSI mobile wallet app is designed with greater preference to the highest security and user privacy standards, while providing an unparalleled user experience.

Our recognition as a finalist in the FIDO developer challenge is a true testament to the dedication of our team. We’re thrilled to have had the opportunity to showcase our work on this platform, and we’re grateful to the FIDO Alliance & FIDO India Working Group team for providing us with this opportunity. We’re excited to continue driving positive change in the digital identity space and helping our clients and users navigate the complex digital landscape with confidence.

Why Passwordless?

Cybercrime damages the world economy $2.9 million every minute, with 80% of cyberattacks targeting passwords. The Indian Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-In) has warned that online users in the country are being targeted by phishing scams, which involve an attacker fooling a victim into clicking malicious links in order to steal sensitive data like passwords, login information, and One Time Passwords (OTP). In India, the National Crime Record Bureau reported 4,047 cases of online banking fraud in 2020, with 1,093 of those cases involving OTPs. The recent global epidemic has increased enterprises’ readiness to adopt password-less FIDO Authentication, making it easier to solve than ever before thanks to the rising number of devices supporting FIDO and the availability of a public WebAuthn API.

To summarise

At AyanWorks, we remain committed to delivering innovative digital identity solutions that meet the needs of our users, while prioritising security and privacy. Our recent recognition as a top finalist in the FIDO developer challenge validates the quality of our solutions and motivates us to continue pushing the boundaries of innovation further. We believe that building strong relationships with our fellow developers and industry leaders will enable us to drive positive change in the digital identity space. If you’re interested in learning more about our solutions or partnering with us, please visit our website or reach out to our team. We will be happy to share the details and also arrange for you a quick demo of our solution.

You can contact us here. You can follow us for all future updates.

Until then, happy hacking the solutions..!

:: More about Passkeys: https://passkeys.dev/

11:08 • 9 days ago

Ocean Protocol

Ocean Protocol partners with Orbis to launch end-to-end encrypted messaging on Ocean Market

Ocean Protocol, the decentralized smart-contract platform for data sharing and monetisation, has integrated with Orbis, the Web3 social protocol allowing end-to-end encrypted communication between users. This integration provides all users of the Ocean Market with the right tools to engage and communicate with data buyers and sellers — all in a privacy-preserving environment. Data buyers are now

Ocean Protocol, the decentralized smart-contract platform for data sharing and monetisation, has integrated with Orbis, the Web3 social protocol allowing end-to-end encrypted communication between users. This integration provides all users of the Ocean Market with the right tools to engage and communicate with data buyers and sellers — all in a privacy-preserving environment.

Data buyers are now able to request and exchange information with data sellers, as well as collaborate with other data providers to create whitelisted compute-to-data algorithms for their datasets. At the same time, data sellers can provide hands-on customer support across their portfolio of data assets, which in turn helps increase customers’ confidence in their product offering.

Empowering data buyers to effectively convey their data requirements and collaborate with reliable sellers leads to the development of innovative data products and services as well as facilitate the creation of more advanced algorithms, leading to deeper insights from the data.

This integration is just the beginning of our collaboration, which aims to explore new opportunities to empower individuals to unlock the value of their data while maintaining privacy and security.

About Ocean Protocol

Ocean Protocol is a decentralized data marketplace that enables data providers to monetize and share their data in a secure and transparent manner. The platform allows data buyers to discover, access, and consume data from a wide range of sources, including individuals, businesses, and institutions. With a focus on data interoperability, Ocean Protocol enables data to be shared and consumed across different domains, industries, and applications, creating a new era of data collaboration and innovation.

About Orbis

Orbis is a privacy-preserving social protocol that enables secure communication and collaboration between individuals and organizations without compromising their data privacy. Orbis enables end-to-end encrypted conversations with the implementation of Lit protocol’s threshold cryptography and encryption parameters, ensuring user privacy and preventing unauthorized access to user data. Orbis’s innovative approach to privacy enables individuals and organizations to collaborate and share data in a trustless and decentralized environment.

Follow Ocean Protocol on Twitter, Telegram, LinkedIn, GitHub & Newsletter for project updates and announcements. And chat directly with other developers on Discord.

Ocean Protocol partners with Orbis to launch end-to-end encrypted messaging on Ocean Market was originally published in Ocean Protocol on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

09:59 • 9 days ago

Nuggets

Nuggets: The Only Decentralized Identity Merging Identity, Compliance, and Payments

In the information age, trust, privacy, security, compliance, and user experience are paramount. While last-gen identity solutions based on passwords, emails, devices, and wallet addresses are still prevalent, people are paying for this convenience with one of their most valuable assets — personal data. The emerging Web3 makes the problem of data security and fraud more immediate, but it als

In the information age, trust, privacy, security, compliance, and user experience are paramount. While last-gen identity solutions based on passwords, emails, devices, and wallet addresses are still prevalent, people are paying for this convenience with one of their most valuable assets — personal data.

The emerging Web3 makes the problem of data security and fraud more immediate, but it also provides solutions.

Decentralized identity systems promise to empower users to verify themselves and conduct online transactions without disclosing their personal information. However, many existing platforms can’t offer a holistic solution that addresses critical aspects like digital identity, interoperability, user data security, compliance, and payments — that’s where Nuggets makes the biggest difference.

Nuggets is the only product that enables organizations to comply with regulations whilst maintaining their privacy, guaranteeing data security, and remaining fully decentralized. As a super-wallet, Nuggets also enables multi-rail payments and provides a convenient cache for crypto assets — all tied to a verified decentralized identity.

Best of all, Nuggets is available globally right now.

More power to you

Requiring just one-time onboarding during sign-up, Nuggets focuses on providing a user-friendly, secure, and interoperable experience across Web2 and Web3. The solution provides a merit-based reputation and prioritizes protecting users’ data — enabling them to navigate the digital world with confidence and ease.

By leveraging a combination of Self Sovereign Identity (SSI), auditable nuggets of data, Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs), peerDIDs, and verifiable credentials, Nuggets has created a state-of-the-art solution that puts privacy and security at the heart of its design.

Users’ identification is linked to W3C verifiable credentials and ZKP proofs, allowing them to confirm their status without revealing any private information.

Nuggets is also a fully customizable, ready-to-deploy solution that supports real-world use cases. As such, brands can seamlessly integrate Nuggets into existing infrastructures, compliance processes, payments, and customer experience immediately or offer Nuggets as a standalone identity solution.

One of the most critical challenges facing Web3 is complying with regulations without requiring users to hand over a litany of personally identifying information to a centralized third party. Until now, there has been no decentralized way for Web3 protocols to do this.

Solving this issue, Nuggets features built-in tools to ensure compliance with the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) and The Financial Action Task Force’s (FATF) requirements, including Know Your Customer (KYC) and Anti-Money Laundering (AML) procedures, without compromising decentralization, privacy, or autonomy. Whether you’re an individual, DeFi protocol, exchange, or DAO Nuggets creates a frictionless, secure experience and reduces the risk of cybercrimes while simultaneously ensuring users’ privacy and security and increasing operational efficiency. Nuggets’ self-sovereign identity solution also serves as a critical entry point for DeFi, as it allows users and service providers to operate in a verified, compliant environment.

Cultivating a Vibrant Web3 Ecosystem

Nuggets’ vision goes beyond creating a cutting-edge identity solution — it is committed to nurturing collaboration and adoption within the Web3 ecosystem. Companies like Collab.Land and Yieldly have already embraced Nuggets’ vision in its pursuit of a safer, more private digital future.

These partnerships highlight how Nuggets is being harnessed to boost user control, interoperability, compliance and privacy across a wide array of applications, from decentralized finance (DeFi) and non-fungible tokens (NFTs) to Web3 communities.

Nuggets’ solution has the potential to spark a profound transformation in industries as diverse as e-commerce and healthcare, allowing everyone — people of all ages, backgrounds, and businesses — to benefit from its identity solution.

By incorporating Nuggets into their systems, companies can simplify onboarding processes, elevate user experiences, and protect sensitive information without compromising on convenience.

Together, we are building a future where digital identity is private, secure, user-centric, and empowering.

If you’re looking to enable identity, compliance, or payments, we’d love to work with you.

Request a demo with Seema at partner@nuggets.life

Nuggets: The Only Decentralized Identity Merging Identity, Compliance, and Payments was originally published in Nuggets on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

09:44 • 9 days ago

Dark Matter Labs

CircuLaw — using existing laws and regulations to accelerate the transition to a circular economy

CircuLaw — using existing laws and regulations to accelerate the transition to a circular economy CircuLaw is an open public service that is aiming to accelerate the circular economy transition by enabling policymakers to make more and better use of existing laws and regulations. CircuLaw.nl is a digital platform that presents opportunities within the existing legal and regulatory framework
CircuLaw — using existing laws and regulations to accelerate the transition to a circular economy

CircuLaw is an open public service that is aiming to accelerate the circular economy transition by enabling policymakers to make more and better use of existing laws and regulations.

CircuLaw.nl is a digital platform that presents opportunities within the existing legal and regulatory framework in the Netherlands in an accessible, digestible and ultimately implementable way. Over the past two and a half years, we (Dark Matter Labs) have been working alongside the City of Amsterdam, and various knowledge and funding partners to conduct research, design, develop and launch alpha and beta versions of CircuLaw.nl. The platform currently enables policymakers to explore opportunities around 3 themes: sustainable timber construction, wind turbines and mattress production chains. More themes will follow.

CircuLaw.nl — English page Introductions, and some context

CircuLaw builds upon Dm’s work supporting regulatory innovation in Montreal (Canada), Madrid (Spain) and Copenhagen (Denmark). In 2019, we engaged with the City of Amsterdam as part of EIT Climate-KIC’s Deep Demonstrations programme. In Amsterdam, we have an innovative and forward-thinking partner, the city has embraced the doughnut economic model and has a relatively large and growing number of staff devoted to innovation and accelerating its circular economy transition.

The Netherlands is aiming for a fully circular economy by 2050. Setting targets is a vital first step, but meeting such targets requires immediate and drastic changes in the way that we produce, build, manufacture and consume. According to the Circularity Gap Report (2022) increased material extraction means our economies are becoming even less circular — shockingly, global circularity has shrunk from 9.1% in 2018 to just 7.2% in 2023.

Research from the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency states that the drastic changes we now need cannot rely only on policy aiming to support and facilitate circularity initiatives of parties that are mainly experimenting, but also if we are serious about reaching circularity goals, then we cannot exclusively focus on making changes in laws and regulations; the public sector must use current regulatory powers much more effectively to compel rapid change across wider society.

Making and implementing new regulations is time-consuming, so back in late 2019 and early 2020, Amsterdam was already pondering how it could make better use of existing ‘hard’ instruments — the components of its current legal, regulatory or taxation systems — to begin accelerating change. Even among municipalities leading the battle against climate breakdown, these existing hard instruments remain largely underutilised. According to Royal HaskoningDHV’s 2022 research such directive use of regulations accounts for only 1% of activity.

Circular Activities of local and regional authorities (Royal Haskoning, 2022)

Having spent almost two and a half years working around policymakers in Amsterdam and the wider Netherlands, we recognise how incoherent the legal and regulatory system can seem. Firstly and fundamentally, pivoting towards a circular future requires the use of a regulatory system that was never developed to drive the transition to a circular economy. For policymakers with circular economy goals, navigating this regulatory system forms a formidable obstacle.

Accessing and evaluating the relevant information and policy options takes a lot of time and requires expensive legal expertise, so when a return on that investment is uncertain, policymakers are often deterred from exploring possibilities. In instances where legal support is sought, it also tends to be highly specialised, because the different parts of the regulatory system are so fragmented. Even in the rare instances where a legal or regulatory instrument is successfully used to bring about policy change in a municipality or province, information about the outcome tends to remain localised and knowledge is rarely passed on. As a consequence, policymakers across the Netherlands still opt to pursue change via more voluntary agreements (covenants) and innovation subsidies, irrespective of their chances of making the necessary impact. Assertive use of legal and regulatory opportunities remains ‘too damn difficult’, even though we won’t get much further without it.

CircuLaw’s solutions

In response to this, CircuLaw attempts to piece the fragments together; to make the Dutch regulatory system more easily accessible to its policymakers by quickly directing them towards relevant instruments and information.

Behind the scenes, we’re analysing existing laws and regulations, extracting relevant instruments and then translating the findings into understandable, readable, shareable, applicable insights; policymakers in all levels of government can use these as starting points for shaping actionable policies.

By combining this analysis with a breakdown of innovations that did (and didn’t) work, CircuLaw aims to provide an overview of the current systems and practices. To do the legal analysis we created the following replicable methodology:

CircuLaw’s methodology for law analysis Methodology for law analysis

1. Choosing theme
We’re choosing themes or product groups (e.g. wind turbines) based on impact, influence, momentum and existing opportunities.

2. Researching theme
Defining how the chain of the product is put together, understanding who plays a role in this, which circular processes are already in place, etc. This analysis helps us to see which (technical and policy) solutions are already available for some problems and which ones still need to be developed, leading to a set of operational goals.

3. Demarcating laws
Identifying laws and regulations that can help us achieve the operational goals.

4. Analysing laws
We’ve developed an analysis key to thoroughly examine laws and regulations at local, provincial, national and soon also EU level to identify relevant instruments and opportunities.

5. Ranking opportunities
Based on the influence of an instrument in practice and its legal feasibility we rank the instruments.

6. Translating legal language
To be readable and understandable by policymakers without a legal background we present our content without using jargon.

7. Creating overviews
Our overviews allow policymakers to explore findings according to authority level, the way the instruments interrelate or as a filterable list.

Different instrument overviews based on authority level, how instruments interrelate and as a filterable list. For the interactive overviews see circulaw.nl Some things we have learned so far

The shift towards a systemic policy focus on the circular transition is only really getting started, though there’s increasing appetite for the work and it’s taking place with a growing sense of urgency across all layers of government in the Netherlands. But when it comes to learning and measuring impacts, there’s still vast terrain left to explore. CircuLaw is among several initiatives working across the Netherlands to accelerate change. It’s still early days, but we’ve been given the space to co-create a flexible, iterative tool to best serve the particular requirements of its end users. Here are a few lessons we’ve learned over the past two and a half years.

1. We need to be sensitive towards existing policymaking and implementation processes

When we began working with policymakers in different parts of the municipal organisation, we were aiming to closely witness — and perhaps map — their policymaking processes. Almost immediately, we started to realise the sheer diversity of policymaking and implementation processes. Each policy domain relevant to the circular transition (and there are more than one might imagine) has its own practices and logic; and all policymakers bring their own knowledge, experiences, networks and approaches. Every potential instrument has its own implementation journey requiring expertises scattered across several departments and teams, and this work all takes place within differently structured municipal organisations with their own hierarchies, internal politics and working cultures.

As a result, policy making is both relational and non-linear, so working out how to help at a generalised level presents a challenge. Top down, one-size-fits-all approaches are doomed to fail.

A simplified illustration of the context of a policy maker timber construction — drawing by Yvonne de Meij van Streefkerk (Team CircuLaw)

2. We’re focusing on the policymaking frontrunners

Amsterdam has a team devoted to its circular economy transition, positioning the city at the vanguard amongst global capitals. As our work has expanded across the Netherlands, we’ve opted at this stage to cater to those municipal practitioners prepared to experiment and take greater risks in their policy-making decisions. Some of the approaches and discoveries might not be immediately applicable in a municipality with 0.5 FTE working towards a circular economy, but we’re aiming to establish precedents amongst frontrunners that then show a growing body of evidence to inspire and enable colleagues in organisations with less in-house capacity. By demonstrating and documenting a wide range of cases at the edge of current practice, we hope to create a real shift in what is considered possible within the current rules and regulations in cities across — and beyond — the Netherlands. And we hope it will contribute to a better shared understanding of where actual changes in the law are needed to further accelerate change.

3. We need to support both replication and innovation

There’s still plenty of potential for change using the existing regulatory system. Identifying and mapping relevant legal and regulatory instruments around different themes and product groups will begin to increase navigability and coherence, but then successfully utilising those instruments to change outcomes is a different matter. When an existing legal instrument has been implemented, CircuLaw.nl can provide a step-by-step walkthrough of how change has been achieved, with examples and shared lessons. This approach could stimulate replication and greater uniformity across the Netherlands — critical for shaping e.g. the investments of suppliers of goods and services to the government.

While there is definite value in documenting previous successes, we also need to establish ways to support policymakers who are looking to do unprecedented things; to give them the tools and confidence to innovate using (existing) legal instruments that might have been previously overlooked or underutilised.

4. We’ll need help to monitor and measure impact in a complex, adaptive system

There are so many factors involved in any policy making process that claiming impact or attributing causality can be difficult. At some level we need metrics to establish whether we’re doing the right things, but, however effective, regulatory instruments are only ever a part of the policymaking picture.

Some impacts of CircuLaw might be relatively straightforward, others might take ten years to take full effect. It’s never going to be as simple as measuring the increase in % of instruments used, because a single instrument might account for repeated change. So we’re exploring the best way of working with the City of Amsterdam’s Monitoring team to look at material flows, such as concrete or food, to establish what would be most useful to measure.

CircuLaw is also about increasing shared awareness about possibilities in law and regulation. We’ve already seen an example of a circular economy team hiring a legal policy expert, recognising it’s important to have this knowledge within their team, or hearing people say, “OK, we’ve seen what you are doing, we are going to see how we can work more like that”. This shows the kind of early impact that can lead to later successes, and any measurements of impact will have to be a mixture of qualitative and quantitative findings.

5. The value of working in an ecosystem

In co-creating CircuLaw, we’re working in an expanding ecosystem. We’re not just developing ideas internally and then encouraging their adoption within a municipality. Instead we’re forming a team between organisations. The collaboration started between Dm and the city of Amsterdam, but has now expanded to include a variety of public institutions, legal experts and funding partners from across the Netherlands. Together, we’re developing a platform and testing ideas with and for experienced policymakers.

As a small organisation Dark Matter Labs is able to move with greater agility than a large municipality, but developing CircuLaw requires a range of expertise and experiences. Dm brings strategic designers, system thinkers, developers, visual designers and user experience designers, and CircuLaw requires us to orchestrate an ecosystem of people with deeper policymaking expertise, greater experience of governmental operations, legal expertise and context-related circular economy knowledge.

We’re still thinking uncompromisingly about what needs to happen, and how it might be possible, but alongside policymakers who’ll work with it every day because if CircuLaw is to have any impact then it needs to be used.

6. Public tech has to be created with and for humans

While we began this blog by stating that more assertive approaches are required — top-down, government-led public tech projects cannot expect to be fully embraced. Successful public tech needs to recognise human experience in all of its messiness. While this might occasionally require non-linear co-creation processes, it will ultimately result in products that better reflect the end users’ reality. By entering a process of consistent user testing and iteration, we’ve not only developed a clearer understanding of how policymakers approach their work, but also the transition their work is having to undergo.

Next Steps

So far, we’ve co-created a small, manageable platform, but to demonstrate viability beyond the Netherlands, CircuLaw will need to cover many more themes, incorporate wider legislation (e.g. EU), and develop a more sophisticated taxonomy of relevant legal instruments. Our ambition is to pass the hosting and running of CircuLaw to a national organisation by the end of 2024, but before that’s possible, there’s still lots of work to be done.

1. A continuous dialogue with Dutch policymakers

In order to make CircuLaw part of the Netherlands’ wider circular economy policy landscape we’re collaborating with a community of practice to better understand how policymakers go about their work, to help more fully recognise the practical barriers that policymakers tend to run into when attempting to use instruments, and to create an avenue for feedback. From this we’re looking to establish whether policymakers want extra information, whether they want courses, or workshops or templates to give them increased confidence when navigating the legal and regulatory system.

2. More themes in more places

Amsterdam provided a very suitable environment to initiate the CircuLaw platform, but to stand any chance of accelerating the wider circular economy, CircuLaw needs to exist beyond the confines of a single municipality or country. A lot of the regulation currently on the platform also applies to the wider Netherlands but the next step is to begin incorporating EU Law. We’ve already authored three white papers on this subject. We’re currently exploring food, solar panels and other product groups as additional themes.

3. Maintaining the CircuLaw platform

While we’re still testing and continuously improving the platform, we can be highly responsive in adapting the design and implementing required changes. Once more fully embedded, CircuLaw will require regular maintenance in order to expand thematically, ensure that information is kept up to date, and allow users to submit feedback and access support when required. In order to remain open and accessible to public sector users and other circular economy actors, we imagine the type of organisation that would host CircuLaw for the long term needs to maintain a non-commercial model, and without a paywall.

4. Improving the methodology and its execution

The current execution of the legal analysis methodology requires time and capacity; it’s human endeavour. No doubt much of this will always remain the case; but for the CircuLaw approach to be replicable, scalable and easy to update we’re looking to see what parts of this methodology could be done in more efficient ways; we are hoping to explore possibilities in AI and Natural Language Processing to improve and accelerate legal analysis and translation capabilities, alongside the more creative research work.

Get in touch

If you’d like to know more, or have suggestions, questions or thoughts then get in touch with Romy@darkmatterlabs.org — as this project is part of a collective endeavour to accelerate the transition to a more circular economy (and to transitioning to a just, regenerative economy more in general), we are keen to hear any feedback that can help us and others learn to achieve these goals together.

The current platform is mostly in Dutch, but we’re working on translating it into English. Look out for updates via the CircuLaw LinkedIn page.

CircuLaw partner overview

CircuLaw — using existing laws and regulations to accelerate the transition to a circular economy was originally published in Dark Matter Laboratories on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Identity North

PREVIEW: Allan Foster – Does Trust Matter? Coming to IdentityNorth 2023 Spring Symposium

For consumers, organizations and companies alike, the topic of digital security has become increasingly paramount in recent years, especially with the rise of digital fraud and scams. With this in mind, Allan Foster's upcoming session, "Does Trust Matter?" at the IdentityNorth 2023 Spring Symposium is generating significant interest. As a retired identity and digital [...] The post PREVIEW: Alla

For consumers, organizations and companies alike, the topic of digital security has become increasingly paramount in recent years, especially with the rise of digital fraud and scams. With this in mind, Allan Foster’s upcoming session, “Does Trust Matter?” at the IdentityNorth 2023 Spring Symposium is generating significant interest.

As a retired identity and digital security professional with a career spanning 40 years leading and guiding teams at Apple, Netscape, AOL, Guru Associates, Microsoft, Intel and Sun Microsystems, Foster has an extensive background in the field. He most recently served as the Vice President of Global Partner Success at ForgeRock, a leading provider of digital identity solutions. His wealth of knowledge and experience make him well-equipped to discuss the key trends and tactics impacting the digital environment on a global scale.

One of the main issues Foster will address at the virtual two-day event is the importance of securing digital identities. As more people conduct business and social activities online, it is becoming more crucial to protect against scams and social engineering. This is especially true in Canada, where digital fraud is on the rise. Foster will provide insights into the tactics and technologies that can be used to protect consumers and organizations in this critical time.

Additionally, Foster will also delve into the darker side of identity. As he has noted in the past, “One of the problems of identity is that it has a very dark side in as much as it enables authoritarianism.” This statement underscores the importance of understanding the complexities of digital identity and the need for responsible practices.

Foster’s session is just one of the many compelling presentations being offered at the symposium and the event as a whole promises to be an engaging and informative learning and networking opportunity for digital security professionals & experts and anyone interested in digital security and identity.

Attendees can expect to gain valuable insights into the current state of digital security, as well as practical strategies for protecting their businesses, and personal digital properties and platforms against fraud and scams. In addition to Allan Foster’s session, there is a full stream during the Spring Symposium dedicated to Safeguarding Digital Infrastructure/Cybersecurity.

Register for the IdentityNORTH Spring Symposium to hear Allan Foster and other Canadian and international leaders driving Canada’s digital future.

The post PREVIEW: Allan Foster – Does Trust Matter? Coming to IdentityNorth 2023 Spring Symposium appeared first on IdentityNORTH.

18:13 • 10 days ago

Ocean Protocol

Capitalize with Ocean Protocol: A SMA Algorithmic Trading Tutorial

Why Trade Crypto? While there are many reasons that people become interested in trading cryptocurrencies, the following are three main reasons that attract investors: portfolio diversification from traditional financial assets high volatility opportunities around-the-clock 🕚 24/7 trading activity. Algorithmic trading can help you stay solvent in this non-stop financial market. Why? Bec
Why Trade Crypto?

While there are many reasons that people become interested in trading cryptocurrencies, the following are three main reasons that attract investors:

portfolio diversification from traditional financial assets high volatility opportunities around-the-clock 🕚 24/7 trading activity.

Algorithmic trading can help you stay solvent in this non-stop financial market. Why? Because algorithms can trade at all times, even while you are sleeping! 😴 To start your algorithmic trading journey, we offer you a momentum strategy using the Simple Moving Average (SMA). We will also introduce Ocean Protocol, an open-source data sharing ecosystem of tools that can allow traders to sell the output price predictions of their algorithms!

Figure 1. Golden and Death Cross technical indicators are shown on a time series chart of BTCUSD prices. What are Golden & Death Crosses?

What does SMA have to do with golden and death crosses in trading? What are they? A golden cross is a bullish indicator that happens when the SMA 50 crosses above the SMA 200. Why is that bullish? 🐂 Because the SMA 50 moves faster relative to recent price changes than the SMA 200, so this cross shows that the latest prices are moving upward. 📈 The opposite case, when the SMA 50 moves below the SMA 200, is a death cross and is a bearish indicator 🧸 that indicates a downward trend in the latest prices. 📉

Golden and Death crosses are shown in Fig 1.

The Simple Moving Average Explained Simply! 🧑‍🏫

So how is the SMA calculated? SMA is the average of a time series of prices in a window of a fixed length. The technique is called “moving” because the window slides in accordance with the time series. A time window of 200 days is typically used for computing the “historical trend” and a window of 50 days is used to compute the “current trend” in golden/death cross strategies. Of course, it is possible to form a golden or death cross interpretation on different SMA indicators, such as the SMA 5 versus the SMA 20 for higher frequency trading decisions for example. In this tutorial, however, we will stick with the traditional SMA 50 and 200 day indicators. We’ll show you how this works in the code below!

Let’s Trade!

Using the SMA 50 & 200 day indicators, we show you a quick algorithm to detect that glorious Golden cross buying signal 💰 and ominous Death cross selling signal 💀. Check it out below:


# Get 201 days of data
eth = get_ethereum_201_days_data()

# Use 200 days to compute SMAs from the day before
sma_day_before_200 = sum(eth[:200]) / len(eth[:200])
sma_day_before_50 = sum(eth[:50]) / len(eth[:50])

# Use 200 days to compute SMAs from the current day
sma_current_day_200 = sum(eth[1:]) / len(eth[1:])
sma_current_day_50 = sum(eth[1:]) / len(eth[1:])

# Detect Cross
day_before_diff = sma_day_before_50 - sma_day_before_200
current_day_diff = sma_current_day_50 - sma_current_day_200

# Golden Cross
if day_before_diff < 0 and current_day_diff > 0:
advice “buy”
# Death Cross
else if day_before_diff > 0 and current_day_diff < 0:
advice “sell”
# No Cross
else:
advice “do nothing” On Maximizing Profit

Did you know that you can tune the window length for the SMA calculation to optimize your profits?

We show you how to do a grid search using different SMA time windows over the last 6 years of historical ETH data to find optimal buying and selling points. This way, we select the time window with the highest returns for the trading strategy.

The Grid Search Algorithm:

Select multiple combinations of time windows to compute historical and current trends. The historical trend window should range from 10 to 210 days with a step of 10 days, while the current trend window should range from 5 to 50 days with a step of 5 days. Perform the trading strategy for each combination. Simulate transactions for a year, from January to December, at the beginning of which the trading return and investment are zero. Execute purchases and sells during the year based on the algorithm signals, and calculate the return on the last day of December for each year. Obtain a return value for each combination of time window. Analyze the results by averaging the returns per year and per window combination to determine which window size combination consistently yields the highest returns across years.

The colorful Figure 2 below shows all the different time windows we tried in our grid search for trading over 6 years. The brighter the color, the higher the percentage of total return. And guess what? We found out that the sweet spot for computing the current trend is between 10 and 20 days, while for historical trend it’s between 30 and 50 days. Time to put our findings to good use and capitalize on them!

Figure 2. Percentage return of trading with given different SMA window combinations. Monetizing Your Asset with Ocean Protocol 🌊

Ocean Protocol is an ecosystem of open-source tools that share datasets and algorithms on the blockchain. 🐙🐬 In this tutorial, we’ll publish our algorithm as an NFT with metadata on the blockchain and a corresponding “datatoken” to gate access to the NFT.

Learn more about Ocean Protocol in the Ocean Academy.

Minting an algorithm “dataNFT”

It’s trivial to mint your trading strategy algorithm on the blockchain as a “dataNFT’’ using Ocean Protocol’s Python library, ocean-lib! At the same time we mint the NFT, ocean-lib will also create a datatoken that controls access to this NFT. We’ll be able to sell copies of this datatoken on the blockchain to immediately monetize our algorithm!

First, we pip install the Ocean Python Library.

$ python -m pip install ocean-lib

Type ‘python’ in your terminal to open up the Python console. Let’s code some Python!

$ python

Then, we’ll import all the libraries we need & setup our blockchain as Polygon’s Mumbai test network for this tutorial:

>>> from ocean_lib.web3_internal.utils import connect_to_network
>>> connect_to_network("polygon-test") # mumbai is "polygon-test"
>>>
>>> from brownie.network import accounts
>>>
>>> from ocean_lib.example_config import get_config_dict
>>> from ocean_lib.ocean.ocean import Ocean
>>>
>>> from datetime import datetime, timedelta
>>> from ocean_lib.models.compute_input import ComputeInput
>>> import pickle
>>> import os

Next, you can choose whether to connect your wallet to your system’s environmental variables so that you can use it to pay for the gas fees. Or, you can use Bob to act as the wallet’s owner, as shown in the below code. Note that if you use Bob, then you will have to give him fake Matic to pay for gas. You can put his address in at https://faucet.polygon.technology/

>>> config = get_config_dict("polygon-test")
>>> ocean = Ocean(config)
>>> accounts.clear()
>>> bob_private_key = os.getenv('REMOTE_TEST_PRIVATE_KEY2')
>>> bob = accounts.add(bob_private_key)

Upload your SMA cross strategy algorithm to an open repository (for a full SMA algorithm example, please see the Addendum). The public URL to this file will be encrypted by Ocean so that purchasers of the NFT only get the output of the algorithm instead of the algorithm itself.

To publish the algorithm NFT + Metadata + datatoken using the algorithm’s URL, do the following:

>>> ALGO_url = "YOUR_PUBLIC_URL_HERE"
>>> name = "golden_death_crosses_recommender"
>>> (ALGO_data_nft, ALGO_datatoken, ALGO_ddo) = ocean.assets.create_algo_asset(
name,
ALGO_url,
{"from": bob},
image="pandas/pandas",
tag="pip-all",
checksum="sha256:f85d01f3455431325b7b5b7b18ff26d88c0ca9f9f45383b9147fe596e90917ce",
wait_for_aqua=True
)

>>> print(f"ALGO_ddo did = '{ALGO_ddo.did}'")

Once your algorithm is published as an asset on the blockchain, we’ll create a compute service to run your algorithm on a dataset. At the end, we will only sell the output of your algorithm, rather than the algorithm asset itself.

For this tutorial, you can use the Data asset referenced in this link which is free to use.

Side note: This data asset provides 1000 hours of ETH price, meaning that the algorithm is not going to be able to use windows greater than 42 days.

To add a compute service to the data asset:

>>> ALGO_did = "ALGORITHM_DID_HERE"
>>> DATA_did = "DATA_DID_HERE"
>>> DATA_ddo = ocean.assets.resolve(DATA_did)
>>> ALGO_ddo = ocean.assets.resolve(ALGO_did)

>>> compute_service = DATA_ddo.services[1]
>>> compute_service.add_publisher_trusted_algorithm(ALGO_ddo)
>>> DATA_ddo = ocean.assets.update(DATA_ddo, {"from": bob})

Whichever data asset you use, make sure to have permissions for the Data asset to attach a compute service to it. At Ocean Protocol, we call this configuration feature “Compute-to-Data”.

Consumers of your asset will be able to use your algorithm to generate recommendations on whether to buy or sell ETH.

Let’s begin by using the asset to pay for the service.

>>> algo_service = ALGO_ddo.services[0]
>>> free_c2d_env = ocean.compute.get_free_c2d_environment(compute_service.service_endpoint)

>>> ALGO_compute_input = ComputeInput(ALGO_ddo, algo_service)
>>> DATA_compute_input = ComputeInput(DATA_ddo, compute_service)

>>> # Pay for dataset and algo for 1 day
>>> datasets, algorithm = ocean.assets.pay_for_compute_service(
datasets=[DATA_compute_input],
algorithm_data=ALGO_compute_input,
consume_market_order_fee_address=bob.address,
tx_dict={"from": bob},
compute_environment=free_c2d_env["id"],
valid_until=int((datetime.utcnow() + timedelta(days=1)).timestamp()),
consumer_address=free_c2d_env["consumerAddress"],
)
>>> assert algorithm, "pay for algorithm unsuccessful"

Once the transaction has been made, it’s possible to start the compute job and get the recommendations from our profit optimized algorithm.

>>> # Start compute job
>>> job_id = ocean.compute.start(
consumer_wallet=bob,
dataset=datasets[0],
compute_environment=free_c2d_env["id"],
algorithm=algorithm,
)
>>> print(f"Started compute job with id: {job_id}")

Drumroll, please!

It’s the moment you’ve been waiting for: let’s retrieve the algorithm output to see if we should sell or buy ETH tokens.

>>> # Retrieve algorithm output and log files
>>> output = ocean.compute.compute_job_result_logs(
DATA_ddo, compute_service, job_id, bob
)[0]

>>> suggestion = pickle.loads(output)
>>> assert len(suggestion ) > 0, "unpickle result unsuccessful"
>>> print(suggestion) # “buy!” Ta da! You are done creating a valuable SMA trading algorithm & data feed that you can immediately monetize on the blockchain.

If you have any questions, concerns, or feedback, then we want to hear from you! Connect with us on Discord, you are only 1 message away from reaching Ocean’s core tech team and we love to solve user problems!

Join our server here: https://discord.gg/TnXjkR5

Addendum — Algorithm’s Full Code import json
import os
import pickle
import sys

import pandas as pd

from datetime import datetime

def get_input(local=False):
if local:
print("Reading local file.")

return "file0"

dids = os.getenv("DIDS", None)

if not dids:
print("No DIDs found in environment. Aborting.")
return

dids = json.loads(dids)

for did in dids:
filename = f"/data/inputs/{did}/0" # 0 for metadata service
print(f"Reading asset file {filename}.")

return filename


def run_algorithm(local=False):
hsma = 40
lsma = 12

filename = get_input(local)
if not filename:
print("Could not retrieve filename.")
return

with open(filename) as datafile:
data = datafile.readlines(0)[0]
data = json.loads(data)

uts = [int(xi[0]) / 1000 for xi in data]

# Data is per hour so reformat to per day
ts_obj = [datetime.utcfromtimestamp(s) for s in uts]
eth = [float(xi[4]) for xi in data]
dataset = pd.DataFrame({"y": eth}, index=ts_obj)
resampled = dataset.resample("1D").last()

assert len(resampled) >= hsma, f"Not enough data for windows {len(resampled)} vs {hsma}"

eth = resampled["y"]

# Compute SMAs from the past sample
hsma_day_before = sum(eth[-hsma - 1:-1]) / len(eth[-hsma - 1:-1])
lsma_day_before = sum(eth[-lsma - 1:-1]) / len(eth[-lsma - 1:-1])

# Compute SMAs from the current sample
hsma_current_day = sum(eth[-hsma:]) / len(eth[-hsma:])
lsma_current_day = sum(eth[-lsma:]) / len(eth[-lsma:])

# Detect Cross
day_before_diff = lsma_day_before - hsma_day_before
current_day_diff = lsma_current_day - hsma_current_day

# Golden Cross
if day_before_diff < 0 and current_day_diff > 0:
advice = "buy"
# Death Cross
elif day_before_diff > 0 and current_day_diff < 0:
advice = "sell"
# No Cross
else:
advice = "do nothing"


filename = "advice.pkl" if local else "/data/outputs/result"
with open(filename, "+wb") as pickle_file:
print(f"Pickling results in {filename}")
pickle.dump(advice, pickle_file)


if __name__ == "__main__":
local = len(sys.argv) == 2 and sys.argv[1] == "local"
run_algorithm(local)

Capitalize with Ocean Protocol: A SMA Algorithmic Trading Tutorial was originally published in Ocean Protocol on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

17:26 • 10 days ago

Holochain

Developer Training Recap

They Learned to Build on Holochain

Sharing about the March online developer training and student experiences.

What

This March the Holochain Foundation, collaborating with our education partner Mythosthesia, hosted a four day, online developer training. This training focused on giving developers the skills needed to develop Holochain applications in a clean, simple, and robust manner; and it taught them to reason about distributed systems from an agent-centric perspective.

The weekend following the training we held a two day build event where the newly minted Holochain devs could test their skills and demo their projects.

Who

Holochain partnered with Mythosthesia, the new venture by Marcus Philips who co-founded Hack Reactor and experienced dev educator Muhammad Meigooni, in order to provide world-class instruction to our community. Marcus and Muhammad are really passionate about Holochain and it has been a pleasure working with them to develop this course.

Attending the event was an experienced cohort of 18 developers, which ranged from folks who had been developing on Holochain for years to those totally new to the community. Preparing for this training we conducted extensive tech checks (including a solid grasp of the Rust programming language) and culture interviews to ensure that everyone taking the course would be able to get the most from it and that they could grow into valuable community members.

What Was Built

Our build weekend was short. With only a day and a half of build time before the demo, none of the projects demonstrated had reached an MVP status. However, this is only partially due to the limited time. The developers also chose large and potentially impactful projects that were never meant to be completed in a weekend, ones they all seem dedicated to continuing work on. Their thinking and progress on these projects is inspiring.

While we could gush about how incredible this cohort of developers is, we would prefer to simply show you. The following are some highlights from the demo.

Short Demo Descriptions

Harlan Wood has been working on the TrustGraph technology for Holochain over the last year, but at the build days he got it working with a live application. TrustGraph is a reputation system built for platform interoperability that leans into peer-to-peer networks through its transitive trust algorithm which can be used for things like feed filtering.

Watch this quick video to learn more about how TrustGraph might be used:

John Hopkins started mapping out a DID implementation for Holochain. We won’t speak about this too much right now because identity is such a huge topic and we have separate updates about that coming, but it was encouraging to see a dev, new to the framework, who was thinking about a lot of the same things we have been.

Matt Gabrenya started creating a registry of composable app elements that developers could use to create unique arrangements, easily pulling these elements together. This reminded us of the composable applets of We but for the development layer rather than the user layer.

Without there being a direct connection between the two projects, we can already imagine how this might interface with Generative Objects (GO) founder Walter Almeida’s work. He came to this training with the express intent of integrating Holochain into GO’s Meta Modeler so that it is possible to generate custom Holochain applications in a low code environment. Customizable Holochain applications that anyone can build and publish without needing years of developer experience? Yes please. We’ll definitely keep you up to date as these projects progress.

There was also a crop of projects focused on financial applications.

Joshua Vial and Nicholas Stebbings designed the fundamentals of an app that would make it easy to bootstrap an authority list, based on social trust structures, that would serve to authenticate cross chain and cross DHT transactions, ensuring that ledgers on both sides of an exchange were updated appropriately. Meanwhile Julien Lucca, Ross Eyre, Ché Coelho, and Leo Proechel worked on a credit clearing algorithm that uses agent-centric methods to find debt cycles in B2B contexts and cancel them out. Even the course instructor Marcus Philips spent time refining the design for a protocol he started for a Transitive Favor Network. This would be a radically peer-to-peer currency protocol where each individual would only need agreed-on systems of value exchange with their direct neighbors, but which would allow strangers to still exchange with each other by finding connections through the social graph.

Watch this video of Julian, Ross, Che, and Leo describing their Credit Clearing Algorithm:

Course Reviews

How did the course turn out? Rather then trying to explain a group’s shared experience, we’ll just quote a few of the responses from the students’ course feedback forms:

“I thought this was a really excellent way to gain an introduction to Holochain, and it definitely left me with a thirst to learn more. I think the curriculum is well thought out and gives the perfect HDK 101.” —John Hopkins
“A very cohesive bunch of minds gathered with a yearning for more knowledge and discovery — which makes for a refreshing classroom experience. It is clear that the choice of cohort and instructors was very well considered and this has led to a wealth of knowledge in the room, and excellent coordination throughout.” —Nicholas Stebbings
“I can't think of another class or training I've been in where I enjoy the community as much as I have in this class. I have learned so much from the questions and side conversations.” —Patrick Winfield
“This course has been invaluable and incredibly empowering. It has also been a super-collision of incredibly competent and fascinating folk.” —Ché Coelho
“Super fun and useful! Definitely exceeded my expectations. The course is super grounding and down to earth — getting all the way down to DHT ops and all the way up to capability claims.” —Anon
“The course is great. It provides a thorough grounding in the conceptual building blocks of Holochain, along with the practical tools and experience to build working apps. I would highly recommend it to anyone who wants to learn how Holochain works, what it can do, and how to make it do those things.” —Anon
“The Holochain developer immersive has been exceptionally stimulating. It's helped to solidify my understanding of distributed systems in general and has led to a deeper appreciation of the HC architecture and its potentially integral role in bringing digital technologies into alignment with the human-social organism. Our studio intends to become active developers and supporters of the ecosystem.” —Ross Eyre
“This is an excellent technical deep-dive for developers who wish to write Rust code based directly on the HDK. It is well-constructed, descriptive, paced excellently, and presented by very knowledgeable and passionate people.” —Acea Spades Black
A Self-Paced Online Course

We expect to have more dev training sessions in the future, but in the meantime we are producing a self-paced, online course available to anyone who wants to learn to develop on Holochain.

This course will consist of recordings from the March dev training so that you get the same information and education that we provided to this past cohort. You’ll need to know some Rust, and there won’t be the hands-on element, but by supplementing your experience with online build events, Discord office hours, and the support of our thriving developer community, we think that this course will help you grow as a Holochain developer.

Fill out this interest form and we’ll let you know when the course is live.

16:19 • 10 days ago

Shyft Network

Shyft Dev Deep Dive Monthly — March 2023

Shyft Dev Deep Dive Monthly — March 2023 Welcome to Shyft Dev Deep Dive, your monthly source for the latest Shyft-wide features and technical advancements. March proved to be a busy month for development efforts, and we are enthusiastic about maintaining our momentum in the upcoming weeks. Our focus remains on elevating the user experience for the entire Veriscope community. Throughout Mar
Shyft Dev Deep Dive Monthly — March 2023

Welcome to Shyft Dev Deep Dive, your monthly source for the latest Shyft-wide features and technical advancements.

March proved to be a busy month for development efforts, and we are enthusiastic about maintaining our momentum in the upcoming weeks. Our focus remains on elevating the user experience for the entire Veriscope community.

Throughout March, our Product & Engineering team worked on several key initiatives, including:

(i) Support for Multiple Trust Anchors (MTAs)

(ii) Bloom Filter for deposit addresses

(iii) Veriscope Infrastructure as Code (IaC)

In addition to these initiatives, we are excited to announce that our team has published an external roadmap, providing greater visibility into our ongoing projects and future plans.

And as always, if you would like a demo or have any questions, please email us at Veriscope@Shyft.Network.

Support for Multiple Trust Anchors (MTAs)

As announced in our February Dev Deep Dive, we have introduced support for MTAs, empowering VASPs and Service Providers to manage multiple trust anchor accounts with a single Veriscope instance. This eagerly-awaited feature has been met with positive feedback and excitement.

Bloom Filter for Deposit Addresses

With effective implementation of the Bloom Filter for deposit addresses, VASPs can now effortlessly identify and address relevant attestations — specifically, those associated with addresses under their control. No more sifting through countless attestations — VASPs can now efficiently pinpoint and isolate relevant ones with ease.

Veriscope Infrastructure as Code (IaC)

Veriscope IaC offers a fresh approach to provisioning Veriscope Machines and installing Veriscope. Leveraging AWS, Terraform, and Ansible, this new method simplifies the setup and ongoing maintenance of Veriscope for VASPs.

Browser SDK Update

The Browser SDK, which we mentioned in the last edition of Shyft Dev Deep Dive, has been placed on hold while we explore alternative solutions. Our primary objective is to streamline the onboarding process and minimize infrastructure demands, particularly in development and testing environments. Stay tuned for future updates on this front.

User Signing for Unhosted Wallets

Once the Bloom Filter and Veriscope IaC are launched, our attention will shift to User Signing for Unhosted Wallets. This initiative, which commenced in January, will complete the Veriscope suite, as Shyft attestations are currently geared toward hosted wallets. Exciting times lie ahead!

Summary

By simultaneously working on several development initiatives, the Veriscope Product & Engineering team has exemplified our unwavering dedication to improving user experience. And we will continue pushing the boundaries of excellence.

That’s all for this update. Don’t forget to join us for next month’s edition, where we will bring you exciting news from the development side of the Veriscope universe.

Shyft Dev Deep Dive Monthly — March 2023 was originally published in Shyft Network on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

15:29 • 10 days ago

SelfKey

A Guide to Using SelfKey iD for Digital Identity Verification

With the continuous advancement of technology, the demand for secure and user-friendly online verification systems is becoming more proeminent. Compared to the traditional KYC checks that can be tedious and vexing for users, SelfKey iD may be a better, decentralized solution with its focus on security and privacy. In this article, we will illustrate how SelfKey iD works, the uncomplicated steps i
Summary

As the world continues to advance technologically, we find ourselves more and more immersed in the digital realm. Our digital identities have become just as important as our physical ones, and with this comes the need for secure and reliable online authentication systems. 

However, traditional identity verification methods are becoming increasingly vulnerable to hacking and data breaches. This leads to a growing need for decentralized and more secure alternatives to centralized systems.

SelfKey focuses on providing safer and more reliable identity verification solutions. These options may be easier and more cost-effective than traditional KYC (Know Your Customer) methods.

In this article, we will explore how SelfKey iD works, as well as its innovative features and benefits. We will elaborate on how it differs from traditional identity verification systems and why it may be a better option for individuals in the digital age. 

Highlights  What is a SelfKey iD? How does SelfKey iD work? Minting SBT Access to SelfKey DAO Conclusions What is a SelfKey iD? A brief introduction

SelfKey iD is a cutting-edge technology that may revolutionize the way we verify our identities online. With its innovative on-chain credential system, SelfKey iD may offer a faster, more secure, and less costly alternative to traditional KYC methods.

This new approach to online identity verification is the result of extensive research, user feedback, and collaboration. SelfKey shares the vision of industry experts such as W3C and the authors of the soulbound token paper to potentially create a modern and reliable identity verification solution.

With SelfKey iD, users may have complete control over their digital identities. They may manage their credentials, store them securely and share them only with the parties they choose. This may not only give users greater peace of mind but it might also help prevent identity theft and fraud.

Overall, it may be a significant step forward in the evolution of identity verification. And, it may have the potential to transform the way we authenticate ourselves online.

Why SelfKey iD?

SelfKey iD has a clear purpose - to provide companies with a streamlined and efficient KYC process that may improve compliance, reduce costs, and enhance customer privacy. 

By leveraging blockchain technology, SelfKey iD may offer a more secure and efficient way for companies to verify the identities of their customers. 

This may not only lead to a better experience for customers but it may also aid companies in increasing their profitability. With SelfKey iD, companies may enjoy a more efficient and secure system, while customers may enjoy a smoother and more hassle-free onboarding experience. 

Ultimately, SelfKey iD may be a win-win for everyone involved.

Ease of Use

For identity owners or data subjects, the ease of use when it comes to digital identity schemes primarily depends on how easy it is to enroll and use their credentials. 

SelfKey iD is designed with simplicity in mind, utilizing soulbound tokens so that users may easily produce their credentials using any non-custodial wallet. 

With SelfKey iD, the enrollment process may be as easy as a one-click option for users, with the heavy lifting happening behind the scenes.

All in all, SelfKey iD may offer a user-friendly approach to digital identity schemes that may make it easy for users to produce, maintain, and use their credentials. At the same time, it might also provide a secure and decentralized solution that meets the needs of the modern digital age.

SelfKey iD vs traditional KYC checks

SelfKey iD may be a better alternative for identity verification, as it may offer a more efficient, secure, and user-friendly approach to KYC.

By using the potential of blockchain technology and smart contracts, SelfKey iD may provide a secure, decentralized, and efficient identity verification process. It may have the potential to eliminate many of the issues associated with traditional KYC methods, possibly making the process more user-friendly and safe. 

Not only that, but with SelfKey iD, users may have complete control over their digital identities and they might exercise their SSID rights more easily than ever before. 

How does SelfKey iD work?

Obtaining a SelfKey iD is a smooth and hassle-free process that prioritizes user convenience without compromising security and privacy. The streamlined procedure may ensure that users have access to a secure and private digital identity that they can trust.

The process 

By following the simple steps outlined by the platform, users can obtain a SelfKey iD quickly and with ease. The steps are as follows:

Users must first log in with their wallet and pay an entry fee.  The next step would be to undergo a KYC verification process. This method is designed to ensure that the user's identity is authentic and that they meet the necessary eligibility criteria. 

The verification process typically consists of: 

performing a selfie check. providing personal information, such as name and address. providing government-issued identification documents, such as a passport. 

Additionally, users will not be able to create duplicate accounts.

Once the KYC process is complete, legible users are automatically approved. The final step in the process is to mint the soul-bound SelfKey ID NFT. This unique digital asset is generated using blockchain technology and is securely bound to the user's digital identity. 

It might serve as proof of identity and it may be used to authenticate the user's identity in a variety of settings, such as:

online marketplaces. financial institutions. other digital platforms, such as social media and videogames.

Even more, as the concept of the metaverse gains popularity, the need for secure and reliable digital identities becomes increasingly important. SelfKey iD emphasizes privacy and self-sovereignty. Therefore, it may be the perfect identity credential for the exciting products and services of the future.

Minting soul-bound SelfKey ID NFT Aggregating Multiple Credentials

By combining different SBT (soul-bound tokens) and identity credentials, SelfKey iD may provide a higher level of verification for the user's identity. 

Credentials which may be aggregated by a SelfKey iD include, but are not limited to: 

Metaproof. KYC credentials issued by SelfKey Network issuers. Traditional accounts, such as: Google, Apple, Discord, Github, Twitter, and the likes. Various identity tokens, such as Binance’s BAB token issued in 2022.

This implementation may have significant advantages over individual credentials, as it may increase the reliability and accuracy of identity verification. And, an increase in reliability and accuracy is crucial for online interactions and services that require trust between parties. 

The more credentials added to the SelfKey iD container, the more trust may be established, and the more reliable and secure the user's digital identity may become.

Furthermore, the integration of multiple SBTs and identity credentials within a SelfKey iD container might provide users with unparalleled flexibility. This may enable them to add as many credentials as they require to establish their identity in a variety of contexts. 

This feature may enhance the SelfKey platform's versatility and utility. It might make it more appealing to individuals and institutions seeking a reliable and secure digital identity solution.

Essentially, SelfKey's implementation of an aggregated credential system in its platform may be a significant step forward in the development of a strong and reliable self-sovereign identity ecosystem.

Attaching NFT series to SelfKey iD

SelfKey continues to prioritize user-friendliness with the introduction of a unique feature that may enable users to attach a distinct NFT series to their SelfKey iD profile picture. This feature may add a touch of personalization and uniqueness to the user's digital identity. Even more, it might reflect the growing trend of NFTs in the crypto space.

Additionally, it may also enhance the user's experience by providing them with more options to personalize and showcase their digital identity. 

Ultimately, the addition of the NFT series feature to the SelfKey iD platform reflects the platform's continued focus on user-friendliness, personalization, and innovation. 

Access to SelfKey DAO

Obtaining a SelfKey iD may provide users with numerous benefits that enhance their experience on the platform and beyond. 

These benefits may include:

access to the governance of the SelfKey Protocol. the ability to mint SELF tokens. participating in staking. exclusive access to member-only channels on Discord. obtaining exclusive collectible NFT packs. registering for KEY.ETH ENS domains. enjoying instant login to partner apps. Minting SELF tokens

Having access to the SelfKey DAO may enable users to mint their own SELF tokens. The token might then be used for various purposes and services on the SelfKey platform. 

This feature may add value to the user's experience and may provide them with more control over their digital identity.

Staking

By staking KEY tokens on their KYC credential, users may mint SELF tokens. Staking on credentials may be a way for individuals to demonstrate confidence in the accuracy of their data. This, in turn, may increase the validity of their credentials. Users may withdraw tokens at any time, although this will result in the termination of SELF token generation.

Exclusive Discord Channels

Access to member-only Discord channels may be another perk of having a SelfKey iD. It may provide users with a community to engage with other DAO members through a designated channel. DAO members may also discuss proposals for the governance of the DAO. 

NTF packs

Exclusive collectible NFT packs may also be available to SelfKey iD holders. This may add a unique and personalized touch to their digital identity. These collectibles are released by the SelfKey DAO, further enhancing their customization and originality.

KEY.ETH ENS domains and SelfKey iD

Moreover, SelfKey iD holders may register for KEY.ETH ENS domains. This might enable them to create unique and easily identifiable domains for their online identity.

Instant login to partner apps

Instant login to partner apps may be another advantage of having a SelfKey iD. This may provide users with a seamless and secure login process across multiple platforms.

Ultimately, the benefits of having a SelfKey iD express the platform's commitment to providing users with a comprehensive, valuable experience. It may enhance their ability to navigate the crypto space with ease and confidence.

Conclusions

In theory, SelfKey iD may be a strong and reliable form of digital identity that might be used for a broad range of use cases in the crypto world. With its focus on user-friendliness, security, and privacy, the SelfKey iD may be well-suited to the needs of decentralized societies and Web3 applications.

However, SelfKey iD may also be suited for traditional Web2 platforms that want to benefit from security and anti-bot features inherent to the SelfKey iD system.

SelfKey iD may not only empower the governance of the SelfKey DAO but it may also provide a model for other decentralized governance systems. By offering powerful, privacy-preserving identity credentials, the SelfKey iD might enable more fair and democratic governance. This way, users may have greater control over their data and identities.

The SelfKey DAO aims to provide new forms of decentralized governance, which may allow members to experiment with different approaches and explore the full potential of the SelfKey iD. 

As the crypto world continues to evolve, the SelfKey iD might play an increasingly important role in enabling secure and transparent transactions across a wide range of platforms and applications.
