17:39 • 15 days ago

Entrust

Use of CRL Reason Codes Updated

The CA/Browser Forum has approved Ballot SC61 with directions as to which certificate revocation lists... The post Use of CRL Reason Codes Updated appeared first on Entrust Blog.

The CA/Browser Forum has approved Ballot SC61 with directions as to which certificate revocation lists (CRL) revocation reason code should be used for a revocation of a TLS certificates.

What is the problem? RFC 5280 provides a list of revocation reason codes, but it is left to each Certification Authority (CA) to determine which code they will use. The result is inconsistency in the reason codes provided in different CRLs.

So why does inconsistency matter as revocation is revocation, right? If the CAs use consistent revocation reasons, then the browsers may be able to use the revocation reason to provide different output to the browser users. For instance, a certificate which has been revoked due to key compromise may be indicating an attacker is using the private key, so the certificate should not be trusted. On the other hand, if a certificate was revoked because it was renewed would mean the original certificate did not have any trust issues. The result may be that the browsers would support hard revocation for some revocation reasons and not for others.

So what is hard revocation? This would mean the certificate should not be trusted, so the website would not be presented to the browser user.

Here is the list of revocation reasons from RFC 5280 with a description as to when the reason can be used.

unspecified (0) – used when no specific reason is provided, a CA right to issue has expired, or for a reason specified in the CA’s CP or CPS, which is not specified in the TLS Baseline Requirements (TLS BRs) keyCompromise (1) – the private key corresponding to the certificate has been compromised, the private key is weak and can be easily computed, or the method to generate the private key was flawed cACompromise (2) – this reason is not applicable to TLS certificates; however a CA can use this reason if an associated CA is compromised affiliationChanged (3) – no use designated in the TLS BRs superseded (4) – the validation of the domain name or IP address is not reliable, the key size or public key parameters are not applicable, or the certificate was issued not in compliance with the TLS BRs or the CP/CPS cessationOfOperation (5) – the website associated with the certificate is no longer in operation certificateHold (6) – not allowed to be used by the TLS BRs removeFromCRL (8) – not applicable privilegeWithdrawn (9) – certificate request was not authorized, certificate was misused, subscriber violated the subscriber agreement, wildcard certificate supports a fraudulent domain name, there is a material change in the information in the certificate, or the information in the certificate is inaccurate aACompromise (10) – not applicable

Ballot SC61 is effective 15 July 2023, so the CAs will be updating their policies and procedures before this date.

Since many CAs also issue other certificates such as Code Signing and S/MIME, we can expect similar revocation reason practices to be used for all certificate types.

The post Use of CRL Reason Codes Updated appeared first on Entrust Blog.

17:37 • 15 days ago

1Kosmos BlockID

What Is Spear Phishing? [Examples & Prevention Techniques]

Social engineering is still one of the most successful forms of attack in the wild, including various phishing attacks. One form of this threat, spear phishing, uses research and user targeting to breach sensitive systems. What Is Spear Phishing? Spear phishing is a social engineering attack targeting specific individuals or groups with tailored, sophisticated, and … Continued The post What Is S

Social engineering is still one of the most successful forms of attack in the wild, including various phishing attacks. One form of this threat, spear phishing, uses research and user targeting to breach sensitive systems.

What Is Spear Phishing?

Spear phishing is a social engineering attack targeting specific individuals or groups with tailored, sophisticated, and fraudulent communications. In a spear phishing attack, the hacker typically gathers information about the target through extensive research, such as their name, job title, or personal interests. The hacker uses that information to create a compelling message that appears to come from a trusted source, such as a colleague or a company they do business with, to get them to part with their credentials.

The goal of a spear phishing attack is usually to trick the target into divulging sensitive information, such as login credentials or financial data, or to install malware on their computer or mobile device.

What Are Some Key Aspects of Spear Phishing?

Spear phishing is different from regular phishing in several key ways:

Targeting: Spear phishing attacks are highly personalized. The attacker behind a spear phishing attack will typically research the target to gather the information that can be used to create a message that appears to be from a trusted source, such as a colleague or a company they do business with.

While regular phishing attacks are typically sent to many people with a generic message, spear phishing attacks include information and messaging that speaks directly to the recipient.

Sophistication: Spear phishing attacks are often more sophisticated and convincing than regular phishing attacks. These attacks are more likely to be professional looking with more obfuscation around spoofing and free of spelling and grammatical errors. Objectives: The objective of a spear phishing attack is often more specific than that of a regular phishing attack. Instead of trying to obtain generic information such as login credentials, attackers may want to trick the recipient into accessing critical systems or information or to initiate financial transactions that only the victim can do.

While spear phishing and regular phishing attacks rely on social engineering tactics to trick targets into divulging sensitive information or installing malware, spear phishing attacks are typically more personalized, sophisticated, and specific in their objectives. As a result, spear phishing attacks can be more challenging to detect and defend against.

How Can I Protect Against Spear Phishing Attacks?

Spear Phishing is a significant threat, but it isn’t an insurmountable challenge. There are several short- and long-term practices and processes that your organization can put into place to prevent spear phishing attacks.

Some of these include:

Education: Employees should learn about attackers’ tactics and how to recognize a spear phishing attack. The common conception that it’s easier to fool entry-level employees over executives has been disproven over the years. With the rising skills of attackers, everyone in a company org chart must understand how these threats work. Verify And Source of Communication: Before responding to an email or clicking on a link, verify the sender’s email address and check the domain name. If you need more clarification, reach out to the supposed sender through an alternate means to confirm their identity. Implement Email Security: Email security measures such as DMARC, DKIM, SPF, and other methods to reduce the risk of your domain name being spoofed in spear phishing attacks. For example, these allow you to whitelist email domains, prevent known spamming domains from sending emails to recipients inside the organization, and insert warning HTML signals into emails from outside domains to warn recipients about the potential for phishing. Don’t Trust Links or Attachments: Don’t click on links or download attachments from unknown or untrusted sources. Even if the message appears to be from a known source, be cautious when links are shortened or appear out of context. Use Multi-Factor Authentication: MFA, especially with biometrics, can add an extra layer of security to your accounts by requiring a secondary authentication method beyond a password. This can prevent everyday credential hacks by making it impossible for hackers to pass MFA login challenges. Sanitize Online Professional Presence: The more information a professional shares on open networks, the more a hacker can use to craft convincing spear phishing attacks. Post only what is necessary and maintain privacy over all other accounts. Use Passwordless Authentication: While passwordless (or even MFA) can’t stop human error, it can simply remove a hacker’s ability to steal credentials from a spear phishing attack.

Following these best practices can help protect yourself and your organization against spear phishing attacks.

How Is Spear Phishing Different from Other Forms of Phishing?

Spear phishing is set apart from other attacks due to its targeted nature and how sophisticated their delivery is.

Consider these different types of phishing attacks:

Email Phishing: This is the most common type of phishing attack, in which attackers send fraudulent emails that appear to be from legitimate sources to trick recipients into revealing sensitive information or downloading malware. Smishing: This is a type of phishing attack that is carried out via SMS or other messaging apps. Attackers trick targets into revealing sensitive information or downloading malware. Vishing: Voice phishing is a type of phishing attack that is carried out over the phone or via video conferencing and chat software. The attacker poses as a legitimate individual or organization and fools the target into revealing sensitive information or performing a specific action, such as transferring money. Clone Phishing: In this type of attack, the attacker creates a nearly identical copy of a legitimate email or website, often using the same branding and layout. The attacker then sends the fake email or link to the target, hoping to trick them into revealing sensitive information.

Spear phishing, and the closely-related threat of “whaling” (or spear phishing that targets high-level executives) can use different kinds of technical approaches like those listed above, layered with the added research and targeting tactics that make these attack vectors more dangerous.

Thwart Spear Phishing Attempts with 1Kosmos Passwordless Authentication

One of the best ways to shortcut successful phishing attacks is to eliminate the need for passwords. While this isn’t foolproof, cutting out the password part of authentication can make it extremely difficult for attackers to access a system.

That’s where 1Kosmsos BlockID comes in. With 1Kosmos, you get the benefits of strong biometric authentication, compliant identity verification, decentralized identity management, and streamlined user onboarding.

With 1Kosmos, you can utilize the following features:

Identity-Based Authentication: We push biometrics and authentication into a new “who you are” paradigm. BlockID uses biometrics to identify individuals, not devices, through credential triangulation and identity verification. Identity Proofing: BlockID verifies identity anywhere, anytime and on any device with over 99% accuracy. Privacy by Design: Embedding privacy into the design of our ecosystem is a core principle of 1Kosmos. We protect personally identifiable information in a distributed identity architecture and the encrypted data is only accessible by the user. Private and Permissioned Blockchain: 1Kosmos protects personally identifiable information in a private and permissioned blockchain, encrypts digital identities, and is only accessible by the user. The distributed properties ensure no databases to breach or honeypots for hackers to target. Interoperability: BlockID can readily integrate with existing infrastructure through its 50+ out-of-the-box integrations or via API/SDK.

If you’re ready to learn about BlockID and how it can help you remain compliant and secure, read more about our Passwordless Enterprise solutions. Make sure you sign up for the 1Kosmos email newsletter for updates on products and events.

The post What Is Spear Phishing? [Examples & Prevention Techniques] appeared first on 1Kosmos.

Anonym

Inside the Massive Projected Growth in the Decentralized Identity Market

Decentralized identity as a new approach to identity management on the internet is exploding, and it’s not slowing down any time soon. The global decentralized identity (DI) market was valued at USD 379.66 million in 2021 and is expected to expand at a compound annual growth rate of 88.2 per cent from 2022 to 2030. By 2027, the DI market is likely to […] T
Decentralized identity as a new approach to identity management on the internet is exploding, and it’s not slowing down any time soon.

The global decentralized identity (DI) market was valued at USD 379.66 million in 2021 and is expected to expand at a compound annual growth rate of 88.2 per cent from 2022 to 2030. By 2027, the DI market is likely to be valued at USD 6,822 million and, by 2030, it is expected to reach USD 102.0 billion.

Silicon Valley research agency, Grand View Research, which released the figures, says increasing cases of identity fraud worldwide are causing the explosion in DI solutions. Federal Trade Commission data from February 2022 show identity fraud incidents increased by about 45 percent globally in 2020. In 2021, Americans suffered total losses of $56 billion from identity fraud.

“Decentralized identity is considered one of the most secured identity solutions that can reduce such identity fraud, thereby driving the market over the forecast period,” Grand View Research says.

Source: Grand View Research Individual user segment of DI market will grow fastest 

Grand View Research’s DI report reveals some interesting market insights, including that the individual user segment of the DI industry is projected to register the fastest growth rate over the forecast period given the privacy and security benefits it offers individual users. 

SMEs and banking are forecast as the fastest growing industry users of the new technology. 

As an example of how enterprises and customers are already embracing DI products and services, Experian reports in its 2021 Global Identity and Fraud Report that 60 percent of global consumers now use a mobile wallet – up from 53 per cent pre-pandemic. 

Explore Anonyome Labs’ new Sudo Platform decentralized identity wallet SDK. 

Identity wallets like the one we offer through Sudo Platform replace passwords with public and private key encryption to give users more secure access, anchored in blockchain technology. Users use the identity wallet to store their verifiable credentials and to present them as proofs when requesting access to products and services. The wallet app also allows for cross-provider end-to-end encrypted messaging. Learn more.

With the continued rise of the surveillance economy, the world needs solutions that improve privacy for everyday internet users. Decentralized identity is widely recognized as the most important privacy technology innovation for the next decade because it gives users unprecedented control over their personal data. 

Decentralized identity-based applications rely on blockchain as the anchor of trust and therefore decentralized identity is one of the most important use cases for blockchain technology. 

Read Dr Ashley Presents on Opportunities and Challenges of Real-World Applications of Blockchain at Australian Event

Industry experts agree all eyes are beginning to turn to DI solutions to solve the challenges of centralized or federated identity management systems. Gartner calls DI a “must-know” emerging technology in its renowned hype cycle of emerging technologies:

Source: Gartner

Anonyome Labs has long recognized the enormous potential of DI, and is considered a leading expert on the technology, which we make available to enterprise customers through our Sudo Platform APIs. 

Talk to us today about how to go fast to market with DI solutions for your customers.

You might like:

Anonyome Labs’ whitepapers on DI

Why Our co-CEO Dr Paul Ashley is in Demand on the Decentralized Identity Speaking Circuit

This is Everything You Should Know About the Metaverse Right Now

One Thing Experts Always Say About Decentralized Identity, the Metaverse and Web3

Simple Definitions for Complex Terms in Decentralized Identity

Our 5-part blog series on DI, which starts with How You Can Use Sudo Platform Digital Identities and Decentralized Identity Capabilities to Rapidly Deliver Customer Privacy Solutions

15:39 • 15 days ago

YeshID

The Linus Tech Tips Hack: Don't Be Next – Follow These Security Tips

Apparently, Linus of Linus Tech Tips, a YouTube channel known for…uh tech tips…didn’t read my blog post on session cookie stealing...

Apparently, Linus of Linus Tech Tips, a YouTube channel known for…uh tech tips…didn’t read ,my blog post on session cookie stealing attacks. Or maybe they read it, and I wasn’t clear enough. Whatever.

The point of this post is to explain how even the best can be vulnerable. So, grab some popcorn, and let's dive in and learn life lessons from Linus.

Act 1: A Cunning Cyber Trap

An unsuspecting Linus Tech Tips team member opened an email containing malware craftily disguised as a mouth-watering sponsorship offer. This sneaky little program wasted no time, swiping session tokens from the victim's browsers (Chrome and Edge) which gave attackers some of the keys to Linus’s kingdom. And what did they do with their newfound power? What anyone would do: stream fake Elon Musk crypto scam videos and delete channel content, of course!

Act 2: Linus vs. The Hackers

At 3 AM Linus and his team embarked on a naked race (seriously, watch the ,evidence--but only after you finish reading this post) to contain the attack.

The team hadn't prepared a disaster response plan. So the team had to make stuff up as they went along. Of course, you’ve got a plan in place, right? If not, subscribe, like, and follow us on LinkedIn and I promise I’ll explain how.. Linus, bless his heart, focused on password security and two-factor authentication. That’s usually the right move, but in this case, the attackers had waltzed in through the session token (or session cookie) their malware stole. Google's tools, ever the trusty sidekicks, glitched and timed out, adding to the team's mounting frustrations. The cold weather in Linus’s room shrink Linus’s patience and, uh, ego. Act 3: The Cavalry Arrived

When all seemed lost, Google's Partner support swooped in, identifying the compromised account and banned it, restoring order and videos to their Tech Tips realm.

The Moral of the Story

What wisdom can we extract from this tale?

Have a plan: Know your services, who has the keys to them, and how to snatch those keys back when needed. Arm yourself with the right tools: Powerful weapons like ,Google Apps Manager (GAM) can help automate Google Workplace processes to speed things up if you’re comfortable with the command-line and maybe some scripts. Not for everyone. Still, they are not enough as they do not cover other services which are vulnerable to this attack, so having a plan for how to kill sessions on all critical services is critical. Keep it simple: If you're looking for a user-friendly ally, consider YeshID, designed to help you manage your security without breaking a sweat. Find out who added the strawberry to the video. A word from our sponsor

YeshID is a next-generation identity and access management solution. The tool is dead simple to use and smart enough to help create a disaster plan, identify and control who has access to what, and mitigate threats with one click. It’s designed to be delightful to use, created with CEOs, founders, and others in mind who wake up to a disaster and wonder why they are still the super admin.

Serious moment: Session Token Theft – Don’t Get Infected

Protecting against session token theft is incredibly hard. You can learn more about this attack in my previous post ,here, but let me summarize it for you: a session token cookie is a way to authenticate you without you needing to type in your password (or ,give your finger) on Every. Single. Action. Think of them as temporary passwords your browser enters for you on every action. These cookies live in your browser storage and are carefully protected. Unless they are stolen via malware, as in this case. Stealing a session token allows the bad actor to authenticate as you without any friction (password, finger, face…)

There is currently no perfect solution to detect and prevent this attack because each website does it differently. If you are on Google Workspace to Enterprise edition, I recommend reducing ,session duration to something that won’t annoy users too much.

Don’t forget other services (if they support it), e.g., ,Manage session duration | Slack. Sorry, ,Kris.

You can go further and enable ,Context-Aware Access, and configure it only to allow access from specific trusted devices, but it only ,covers very specific Google apps, and that doesn’t help Linus as it does not cover YouTube, or third-party services. Or, if you bought GitHub Enterprise and did a SAML integration for that extra Enteprirse-level security, you won’t benefit from Context-Aware Access because that’s ,not covered:

I am optimistic that the future will be better than today. OIDC (OpenID Connect) - the technology most commonly used for SSO these days - has recently approved the specifications for enabling better session management across different websites and apps with ,Final: OpenID Connect Session Management 1.0, and support for forcing a logout with ,Final: OpenID Connect Back-Channel Logout 1.0, but adoption will take some time. Until then: Avoid malware.

In Conclusion:

The Linus Tech Tips hack was a rollercoaster of emotions, but we've emerged from it wiser and more prepared for the twists and turns of the digital security world. So let's raise a toast to learning from other people's misfortunes and staying safe out there, folks!

-- av

15:35 • 15 days ago

Dock

Dock Certs API Is Now Available on Rapid’s Marketplace, the World’s Largest API Hub

Dock's Certs API is now available on Rapid, the world’s largest API Hub where over 4 million developers find, test, and connect to tens of thousands of APIs with a single account.

Zug, Switzerland – March 16, 2023: Dock, a pioneer in the Verifiable Credentials space, today announced the availability of Certs API on Rapid’s Marketplace, the world’s largest API Hub where over 4 million developers find, test, and connect to tens of thousands of APIs with a single account. Dock’s Certs API can easily be integrated into systems to enable organizations and developers to make data fraud-proof and instantly verifiable.

Mike Parkhill, Dock’s Head of Engineering, said, "We are excited to make Certs API available on Rapid to give developers who want to offer Verifiable Credentials and decentralized digital identity features the tools to build quickly and easily. We believe this will create innovative solutions for organizations by leveraging verifiable, fraud-proof data.”

Certs API Features Issue Verifiable Credentials and create decentralized identifiers (DIDs) Data, documents and credentials are made fraud-proof and instantly verifiable through the use of cryptography and blockchain Set automatic expiration dates and remote revocability of validity Put a proof of issuance on the blockchain (anchoring) Send data, documents and credentials directly to users’ identity wallet apps Set up Verification Requests to verify users’ data and enable Wallet-to-Wallet verification and verification on the web Backup encrypted data to the cloud Advanced privacy features such as Selective Disclosure and Zero-Knowledge Proofs Built in the cloud and designed to scale with you Interoperable because Dock uses international standards for Verifiable Credentials and Decentralized identifiers set by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Certs API Benefits for Developers and Organizations

Building with Dock’s Certs API can provide the following results:

Protect documents from manipulation Issue instantly Verifiable Credentials Get to market up to 6 times faster than when creating a verifiable credentials solution from zero Increase efficiency by automating Verifiable Credential issuance

Developers don’t need blockchain and cryptography knowledge to build Verifiable Credential and decentralized identity functionalities. All they need to know are the standard REST protocols.

About Dock

Dock is a Verifiable Credentials company that provides Dock Certs, a user-friendly, no-code platform, and developer solutions that enable organizations to issue, manage and verify fraud-proof credentials efficiently and securely. Dock enables organizations and individuals to create and share verified data.

Customer Use Cases SEVENmile issues fraud-proof verifiable certificates using Dock BurstIQ Makes Health Data Verifiable, Secure, and Portable With Dock Gravity eliminates Health & Safety certificate fraud with Dock Learn More Decentralized Identity Verifiable Credentials Self-Sovereign Identity Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) Web3 Identity Blockchain Identity Management Selective Disclosure How to Prevent Supply Chain Fraud With Blockchain (ask about verification for this) BurstIQ Use Cases That Leverage Verifiable Credentials Blockchain Food Traceability: Enhancing Transparency and Safety What Are Digital Credentials? Data Compliance How to Prevent Certificate Fraud Digital Credential Platform
15:03 • 15 days ago

Indicio

Indicio, SITA and Aruba Deliver Verifiable Credentials for Digital Travel

The post Indicio, SITA and Aruba Deliver Verifiable Credentials for Digital Travel appeared first on Indicio.
Digital travel credentials create frictionless, accurate data verification while preserving data privacy at every touchpoint across the traveler’s journey

By Helen Garneau

The way we travel has changed a lot in recent years. Travelers expect a seamless travel experience from before they get on the airplane to their final destination.

Today, at the Queen Beatrix Airport in Oranjestad, Aruba, the government of Aruba, SITA and Indicio, announced the successful trial  of a new mobile application that enables seamless travel to Aruba.

The app — Aruba Happy One Pass (Aruba HOP) — allows an air traveler to  to create a digital travel credential (DTC) from their passport. The DTC allows the passenger to pre-populate their Embarkation and Debarkation card (ED card) as required for travel to Aruba. The traveler can use the selective disclosure features of the credential to select the specific information they need to share by law to clear immigration — and, critically,  they can do all this before they step foot on the aircraft.

The ability of immigration to verify all this information as authentic and uniquely belonging to the traveler streamlines arrival in Aruba. Pre-filling information directly from a passport ensures greater accuracy and less error, while a simple scan frees travelers from long waiting lines.

Dangui Oduber, Minister of tourism, public health, and sports for Aruba, described the trial as the result of Aruba’s relentless focus on innovation backed by a strategy of seeking collaborative partnerships with a broad range of stakeholders. He said he wants the entire hospitality sector on Aruba to be able to take advantage of the digital technologies behind AHOP to provide visitors to the island with a superlative, “seamless” travel experience.

The Aruba HOP trial resulted in a 64% reduction of the manual entry of passport information into the ED card website, and had an overall 100% error-free clearance rate of participating travelers, meaning the information contained in trial participants’s ED card was digitally verified by immigration authorities to be accurate for all participants.

Here are some of the other ways this app adds value to the overall travel experience:

Convenience
Travel can be stressful, especially when it comes to managing travel documents and clearing immigration. With a digital travel credential that clears immigration before boarding, travelers can have a stress-free and enjoyable travel experience.

Contactless
The COVID-19 pandemic has made contactless interactions a priority in all aspects of life, including travel. This app offers a contactless solution to clear immigration. Travelers can create a digital travel credential using their verifiable credentials, eliminating the need for physical documents exchange.

Security
Verifiable credentials are secure and tamper-proof, making them an ideal solution for digital travel credentials. Any attempt to alter the information in the credential breaks the credential.  This means border protection can quickly clear pre-approved  travelers with the assurance that their documents are authentic.

Compliance
Governments worldwide are implementing strict data protection regulations. This app ensures that travelers’ personal information and travel details are secure and cannot be accessed by unauthorized individuals. This feature provides peace of mind for travelers, knowing that their data is safe and protected.

The next step
Aruba HOP represents a leap forward in digital travel, one that starts with the need for data privacy and delivers the seamless verification that will transform our experience of travel.

Built with the highest level of interoperability using open standards and open source technologies from Hyperledger Foundation, the verifiable credential technology powering the  DTC can be easily integrated into any existing hardware and technology infrastructure.

As the world continues to adapt to the changes brought by new mobile and biometric technologies, digital solutions such as digital travel credentials and verifiable credentials are the easiest way to ensure verification of quality data, a smooth traveler experience, and a privacy-protected method for managing travel.

The post Indicio, SITA and Aruba Deliver Verifiable Credentials for Digital Travel appeared first on Indicio.

13:19 • 15 days ago

Ontology

Meet the Team: Ontology Member, Polaris

What’s your name and where are you from? My name is Polaris and I am from the United Kingdom. I joined Ontology more than a year ago as a community member. Tell us a bit about yourself. What did you study? What are your hobbies? What would your superpower be? I studied business previously. In my free time, I really enjoy martial arts and music — I’m a musician as a hobby and a martial arts
What’s your name and where are you from?

My name is Polaris and I am from the United Kingdom. I joined Ontology more than a year ago as a community member.

Tell us a bit about yourself. What did you study? What are your hobbies? What would your superpower be?

I studied business previously. In my free time, I really enjoy martial arts and music — I’m a musician as a hobby and a martial arts teacher. If I could have a superpower it would be to be able to tell if someone is lying to me.

In your opinion, what makes Ontology stand out from other blockchains?

I think that Ontology’s Decentralized Identities (DID) offering and on-chain reputation metrics make it stand out. DID will play a huge role in onboarding communities from Web2 to Web3, serving as a solid use case that everyone can benefit from.

What is the most exciting part of the project you’re working on for Ontology?

The most exciting part of working with Ontology is being able to interact with people from across the globe. There’s a really rich community, with people from all kinds of backgrounds from all around the world, who speak different languages and work in different fields beyond Ontology. It’s very diverse!

What has been the most important moment in your career so far?

All moments throughout my career have been very important to me, but I really enjoyed helping form the “ONTOvaganza ” campaign.

As we mark Ontology’s five-year anniversary, where do you see Ontology and Web3 going in the next five years?

To the moon.

Telegram Announcement / Telegram English / GitHub / Discord

Meet the Team: Ontology Member, Polaris was originally published in OntologyNetwork on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

11:57 • 15 days ago

Dark Matter Labs

Data’s role for a post-carbon built environment

Part 2: Exploring how new digital tools and better shared data can support zero carbon, bio-based and circular construction. MatR: A digital registry for a building’s material, component and performance data This is part of a series of blog posts introducing the work Dark Matter Labs (DML) has been doing over the past two years as part of the Laudes Foundation funded HCC: EU CINCO project, to supp
Part 2: Exploring how new digital tools and better shared data can support zero carbon, bio-based and circular construction. MatR: A digital registry for a building’s material, component and performance data

This is part of a series of blog posts introducing the work Dark Matter Labs (DML) has been doing over the past two years as part of the Laudes Foundation funded HCC: EU CINCO project, to support efforts to decarbonise construction through the use of low embodied carbon, bio-based materials and the transition to more circular construction practices.

This piece explores how innovation in digital tools and standardised shared data could support the transition to a lower embodied carbon and more circular built environment. It introduces MatR — a digital tool for recording material, environmental impact and performance data for buildings — that we’ve been developing and prototyping with our partners, The Center for Spatial Technologies (CST).

You’ll find links to the rest of the series at the end.

Our built environment is costing us the Earth

The environmental impact of our built environment is astonishing. Buildings are responsible for 40% of global carbon emissions or 10 billion tonnes (Gt) of CO2e each year — when measuring both embodied and operational carbon. This is larger than our global emissions from coal-fired power plants. To meet a net zero scenario by 2030, this figure must fall to below 4 Gt annually.

Aerial photo of a quarry (Adam Rhodes on Unsplash)

At the same time, of the 100 Gt of materials we extract each year globally, construction is responsible for nearly 40%. Waste arising from the construction and demolition of buildings and infrastructure represents more than a third of all waste materials generated in the EU.

Not only are buildings carbon intensive before they’re even finished, but their performance has a significant impact on our health once we start using them. A recent study found indoor air pollution to be responsible for over 3 million deaths in 2020 alone, almost as many as attributed to outdoor air pollution. Whilst long-term exposure to noise from road traffic can make heart failure more likely.

Our built environment is carbon-intensive, wasteful and bad for our health (yasin hm, Ruslan Khadyev & Gregory Pappas on Unsplash)

Given all this, and that we spend 90% of our time indoors, we still fail to accurately track the performance of the space we inhabit.

The ways we currently design, construct, use and reuse our buildings is incompatible with both our planetary limits, and our current global targets for mitigating the dual climate and biodiversity crises. The compounding risks of material scarcity — and knock-on construction product shortages and price volatility — as well as rapidly depleting carbon budget, means we have no choice but to drastically reassess how and where we use materials, whilst making as much use of existing buildings and their components, as possible.

We must carefully weigh up when it makes sense to retrofit a building — taking into account the embodied carbon and material requirement of doing so, compared to the projected operational carbon reduction over its life cycle as well as potential benefit to occupant health — versus making better use of it as is, or deconstructing for reuse. When new construction is critical, we should design and construct for disassembly and reconfiguration, whilst retaining vital data for future reuse. For existing buildings, we must find efficient methods to locate and tag reusable components, logging their specification and current condition, helping to assess how and where they can be reused.

But, we have one big problem — we don’t know what most buildings are made of, or how they actually perform.

Current data limitations

Whilst we’re awash with tools to track our own behaviour; from sleep patterns, to dating habits, and even life expectancy — we currently lack access to shared, robust data on what our built environment is made of, its environmental impact, and how it functions throughout its life.

So what are the main challenges in this space?

Lack of embodied carbon benchmarks: City officials, planners, architects and developers lack localised and typology-linked benchmarks for setting thresholds for embodied carbon and circularity in both new buildings and refurbishments, through building regulations and procurement — in Europe, only Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France and the Netherlands were found to have baseline data of sufficient sample size and quality. Whilst generic emissions databases exist (e.g. Ecoinvent, ICE), these vary in life cycle scope and geographic context. From our experience working with partners in Madrid and Milan, currently there are no standardised emissions databases for benchmarking buildings or for local construction products. Our interviews highlighted this as a key factor which made it difficult to establish incentive mechanisms or attract investment because it reduced certainty on what constitutes a low embodied carbon project and how it should be measured and demonstrated, leading to an increased perception of risk or unclear reward. Lack of component specific embodied carbon data: Whilst Environmental Product Declarations (EPDs) for construction products are increasing — with over 130,000 now available globally — this is still relatively few. It’s therefore difficult for designers, developers and construction professionals to conduct product-specific embodied carbon assessments using standardised data — in terms of format, life cycle scope and geographic context. At the same time, only around half of these EPDs are machine-readable, preventing widespread integration with digital tools. BIM adoption and whole life implementation: Building Information Modelling (BIM) is still not widely used in many geographical contexts, including Madrid and Milan. Adoption amongst European construction companies ranges from 73% in the UK to 35% in France, and 20% in Austria. There’s also a lack of digitals tools and standards to make it easy for designers and developers to integrate embodied carbon and material circularity related decisions in the design process. At the same time BIM files tend to be discarded or remain static once a building is built, losing valuable information for optimising building use and future deconstruction. Missing or inconsistent building performance data: Building performance data — for instance indoor air quality, light and noise levels, water use — is generally considered separately from embodied carbon and material circularity metrics, if measured at all. For facility managers and building owners to make more informed decisions to maximise utilisation of existing spaces and minimise environmental impact of renovations and new buildings, understanding the full picture of building performance and embodied impacts is necessary. Lack of data on reusable products and circularity metrics: A lack of data documenting the condition, specification, location and potential for reuse of building components and materials, makes it difficult for designers and construction contractors to specify reused products. Without recognised certification and standards for reusable products, construction professionals remain hesitant of reuse. At the same time circularity metrics for buildings are yet to be standardised; and whilst a number of recent frameworks and research projects make proposals, they are yet to become mandatory. Data aggregation: There’s a need for digital tools to integrate and aggregate material and environmental impact data from individual components, to systems, to buildings, to cities; to identify local material stocks and track their flows, from the scale of a door handle to a city’s material economy. For instance, tools like Amsterdam’s Monitor, which measures total material flows (including those resulting from the built environment) within the city alongside their associated carbon emissions and other environmental costs, can help cities to monitor their progress towards material circularity.

For a more detailed overview of barriers and opportunities, as well as relevant existing initiatives in relation to innovations in digital tools and data that could support the transition to a lower embodied carbon and more circular built environment, see our Digital tools and data: Briefing document.

What should we do about it?

Whilst it’s useful to understand materials, environmental impact and performance at the scale of an individual building, it becomes exponentially more powerful when aggregated at the scale of cities and regions. Developing these tools in close partnership with municipal governments and city stakeholders will be fundamental to their success and therefore their public value.

Successful solutions in this space should be designed to facilitate mass adoption; by a diverse range of user types; for a spectrum of use cases — from planning teams and developers to deconstruction contractors and reused component certifiers. We feel it will be necessary to identify and develop a standardised approach, aligned to internationally recognised frameworks and regulations — for example Level(s); the Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESPR) and related Digital Product Passports (DPPs); and recently revised Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD) — that integrates with existing digital tools used by built environment professionals.

For these reasons, we believe it’s important to adopt an open-source approach — taking inspiration from tools like Speckle and IFC.js — to foster widespread adoption and enable future adaptation to local contexts and use cases; rather than implementing a closed system using proprietary software.

Through this work, we believe several criteria will be critical:

Make it open-source: Building on existing open source tools and standards to support data exchange from multiple data sources and integration with other architecture, engineering and construction (AEC) software tools whilst enabling users to adopt and extend for diverse use cases. Share data: Data exists on a spectrum, from closed, shared to open. Data permissions will help to unlock public value through sharing built environment data, whilst ensuring access to sensitive data — for example building occupancy or security — requires authentication. Decentralised publishing of data, using open standards, as seen in the Open Banking initiative, can help to standardise sharing across a sector and increase collaboration. Data pooling, of aggregate data from multiple sources, can generate a critical mass of data for analysis and benchmarking across a geography or sector. This may require stewardship from a data institution to act as a trusted intermediary. Build for the web: Developing a tool that can run in a browser will allow the data to be accessed quickly without proprietary software or specialised hardware, enabling different use cases. Whilst designing it to integrate with recognised AEC tools, currently used by built environment professionals, can help users adopt the new tool as part of their existing workflows. Integrate multiple sources: This will require a tool capable of gathering data from multiple discrete sources — whether via external datasets and an application programming interface (API); or wireless sensors in buildings; or user input data — and linked to a 3D BIM of the building and its components. Adopt physical asset tags: It will be necessary to develop a method to encode each unique ID from the digital model to a physical object. This could use proven technologies like RFID tags or QR codes, or adopt novel solutions to embed data in the objects themselves. Align to regulation: Designed to align and integrate with incoming regulation on sustainable products and aligned to the Level(s) sustainable building reporting framework. The recently passed revision to the EPBD will require embodied carbon to be calculated as part of life-cycle global warming potential (GWP), using a harmonised approach across member states. It also invites the inclusion of embodied carbon data, as part of mandatory national energy performance of buildings databases, using the Level(s) indicators. Here, regulation will be critical for driving behaviour change across the industry, and better, open-source data systems can support the implementation of a harmonious approach across Europe. Apply to new builds and retrofits: Given the criticality of retrofitting existing buildings and continuing requirement for new buildings, developing a tool appropriate for analysing materials, environmental impact and performance in both use cases is vital. Neglecting to account for embodied carbon in retrofit projects risks misrepresenting their intended carbon savings and exacerbating the climate crisis. It’s only fairly recently that the industry has started to recognise this, with guidelines and tools emerging to guide retrofit projects on this topic.

For now, these criteria remain assumptions, based on our research and experience to date. We’ll continue to validate and reassess them as we develop and test our approach alongside a range of stakeholders.

A new approach — MatR

A digital registry for a building’s material, component and performance data.

In response to the barriers and design principles, DML together with partners has been working on one possible approach. MatR is an open source, web-based digital tool that aggregates data on what buildings are made of and how well they perform. It creates a secure digital repository for each building with the digital architecture to link multiple data sources — from environmental impact and material circularity data, to component reuse potential and residual value.

MatR proof of concept: A digital registry for a building’s material, component and performance data

MatR enables a range of users — from architects and developers to city officials or deconstruction contractors (more on this below) — to connect data to a live BIM file of a building. This may be technical specifications from manufacturers; environmental impact data from EPDs or life cycle inventory datasets; air quality or noise from indoor sensors; a log of component condition and any repairs; or residual value of components.

This registry of materials and building performance can then be scaled from a building, to a district, to a city or even nation — contributing to a dataset providing the granularity of the constituent materials in a door handle, to the aggregation of material flows across a city. In the future, it could integrate directly with public datasets and dashboards — for instance emerging digital twins and 3D city models. Data permissions would ensure that any sensitive data — for example detailed BIM files or granular energy use data — is only accessible via authentication, whilst open data standards can enable aggregate data to be pooled at the city level to inform benchmarks and analyse material flows.

Data aggregation and sharing — From the door handle to the city

During the planning of a new building, city officials could use city level aggregate data to set planning requirements for embodied carbon or material use. This tool could allow developers and investors — whether commercial, public or civic — to be much clearer on the environmental impact of their projects and drive supply side change via market signals whilst avoiding greenwashing. In the design stage, architects can use specific product-level data to inform their designs and meet benchmarks. During construction, the registry can be used to log the actual components used and specify maintenance or deconstruction requirements. In the use phase, building operators can track building performance, log maintenance processes and monitor the condition of components. At end of life, a digitised inventory pre-populated with deconstruction guides can help contractors disassemble the building and provide a verified dataset on component specification and condition, to better facilitate reuse. This could contribute to a city-wide material reuse platform, identifying when materials are available (or soon to be available) for reuse; where they are; their specification; and what condition they’re in.

At end of life, a digitised inventory pre-populated with deconstruction guides can help contractors disassemble the building and provide a verified dataset on component specification and condition, to better facilitate reuse. This could contribute to a city-wide material reuse platform, identifying when materials are available (or soon to be available) for reuse; where they are; their specification; and what condition they’re in.

We believe this approach can be considered innovative in several ways:

Open source software and shared data approach: To support wider collaboration within the construction sector and between diverse stakeholders, to drive the transition to a post-carbon and regenerative built environment. Some of the more developed initiatives in this area use proprietary tools and closed datasets. Web-based interface and BIM integration: MatR is a cloud-based tool, linked directly to a digital BIM file, connecting multiple different users throughout the building life cycle and extending the functionality of BIM from design through to deconstruction. It does not require specialist hardware or proprietary software licences and aligns to open BIM standards. Existing material passport tools tend to export data from a BIM file, detaching the live file from a material dataset. Integrating building performance data: Understanding the performance of buildings is critical to measuring how efficiently we use materials. We believe tracking building performance alongside environmental impact and circularity of materials is necessary in order to assess the opportunity costs of how we use scarce materials in the built environment. MatR — Proof of concept

As part of the HCC EU CINCO project, we’ve been working with The Center for Spatial Technologies to develop a technical proof of concept (PoC) of this tool — MatR. The PoC currently enables the user to access a BIM file through a web browser; view an inventory of all components; view aggregate data on material mass and embodied carbon for the overall building; and view specific data for select components, including their specification, environmental impact and material circularity (sourced from EPDs).

MatR — Building and component level metrics

The mockup UX for the MatR platform demonstrates how a user could access data for multiple buildings and projects; manage user permissions; set environmental impact targets; and analyse emissions, circularity and performance related data in a single dashboard.

MatR — Data platform UX

The team is in the process of validating the concept through user testing with built environment professionals, including architects, developers and city planners. Feedback will help to inform the tool’s future development and ensure the team prioritises the development of functionality that is most critical.

Why better data matters

The possible impact of material registries can be considered across several horizons.

In the near-term it could enable:

Low carbon material selection and building design: Supporting architects, engineers and developers to design low carbon and circular buildings by selecting low impact and reusable components. Lower the cost and complexity of compliance: Tools like MatR can reduce the costs and complexity associated with complying to sustainability related building regulations, procurement requirements and certifications. Generate local benchmarks: Data collected can contribute to local benchmarks for different building typologies, helping city officials to set more accurate targets within regulation or procurement requirements.

In the longer-term:

Performance-based regulation and contracting of space: Better building data could enable more agile regulation of the construction and use of buildings, based on their performance or outcomes they contribute to. In the future, this could enable the taxation of underutilised assets or those that don’t contribute to public value. Materials accounting: With intensifying material scarcity, price volatility and dwindling carbon budgets making material accounting increasingly important; the availability of robust, shared data on materials and buildings will be vital. Citywide accounting of material flows or component life cycles — for example, ensuring that carbon is sequestered in timber buildings for a sufficient time period and preventing its early release — will help to guide our material use in buildings. Analysing future liabilities: More accurately modelling the depreciation of built assets to assess their future value (including the associated liabilities) could support a new economy for both durable and regenerative materials, incentivising the reuse of materials at their highest utility. Carbon accounting: The use of carbon taxes and possible future implementation of national Carbon Treasuries — public institutions responsible for the national allocation and management of carbon emissions and sequestrations — would require robust, shared datasets for each key industrial sector. With the built environment being a significant contributor to carbon emissions, a sector wide national database of emissions attributed to buildings and their constituent materials, would help efforts to introduce more accurate carbon accounting What’s next

As noted in Part 1, systemic shifts require many levers to interact. Data plays a central role in enabling other levers — including regulation, investment, supply chain and construction practices etc. — to shift. MatR shows what one piece of the puzzle could look like. Together with CST, we’re aiming to continue and expand our user testing over the coming months, as we identify a set of requirements for the next iteration of the tool; with the intention to develop and test it alongside a live construction project for the next stage of development.

Whilst we’ve initially focussed on a new build scenario — where starting from scratch means data can be linked to the BIM file as the design evolves, making the process more straightforward — we consider a renovation or retrofit use case as equally appropriate. We’ll therefore focus future development of the prototype for use in both new build and retrofit scenarios.

We’ll also be investing more time in developing the open-source approach and underlying business model, whilst looking for partner cities who would be interested in co-developing the concept.

If you’re interested in hearing more, collaborating or sharing feedback; or you’re from a city interested in partnering, please get in touch at:

matr@darkmatterlabs.org

Other posts in this series

This is part of a series covering work we’ve been doing to support efforts to decarbonise construction and transition to more circular construction practices. Follow the links below to access the other posts:

Part 1: Overview — Towards a post-carbon built environment Part 2: Data’s role for a post-carbon built environment Part 3: Decarbonising through policy, regulation and procurement (coming soon) Part 4: Towards a sustainable timber value chain in Spain (coming soon)

Data’s role for a post-carbon built environment was originally published in Dark Matter Laboratories on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

11:35 • 15 days ago

Towards a post-carbon built environment

Part 1: Exploring innovations to support zero carbon, bio-based and circular construction. La Borda, Barcelona (Alvaro Valdecantos) This is the first in a series of posts introducing the work Dark Matter Labs (DML) has been doing over the past two years as part of the Laudes Foundation funded HCC: EU CINCO project, to support efforts to decarbonise construction through the use of low embodied carb
Part 1: Exploring innovations to support zero carbon, bio-based and circular construction. La Borda, Barcelona (Alvaro Valdecantos)

This is the first in a series of posts introducing the work Dark Matter Labs (DML) has been doing over the past two years as part of the Laudes Foundation funded HCC: EU CINCO project, to support efforts to decarbonise construction through the use of low embodied carbon, bio-based materials and the transition to more circular construction practices.

The series gives an overview of the initiative; the challenges and opportunities identified; interventions we’ve developed in collaboration with project partners; and learnings we’ve taken from them. Within each post we’ll provide links to key ‘artefacts’ as examples of these, with an explanation of their current status, potential value to key stakeholders and possible next steps.

This piece introduces our focus areas, within the context of the wider project; outlines our whole-systems approach; covers the portfolio of activities we undertook and summarises our learnings. Subsequent posts will dig deeper into each activity area.

Introduction

Since early 2021, Dark Matter Labs has been part of a group of partners supported by the Laudes Foundation to investigate and test ways to accelerate efforts to minimise embodied carbon in buildings, support material circularity and increase the use of low carbon, bio-based materials. We’ve been working on a number of initiatives with the cities of Madrid and Milan, as part of the HCC: EU CINCO project (Healthy, Clean Cities: EUropean CIties for climate-Neutral COnstruction).

Iron ore mine, Erzberg, Austria (Chris on Unsplash); Forest, Serbia (Filip Zrnzević on Unsplash); Building demolition (Jason Mitrione on Unsplash) Why embodied carbon?

Today, buildings are responsible for 40% of global carbon emissions, when considering both operational and embodied carbon. Whilst operational carbon — emissions associated with operating a building e.g. from heating and cooling — currently represents a larger proportion of total emissions, as energy efficiency in buildings increases and energy sources become less carbon intensive, tackling embodied carbon — emissions associated with materials and construction processes throughout the whole life cycle of a building — is now critical. We’ll simply fail to achieve our climate goals without making it a priority, something cities and other built environment actors are slowly starting to recognise at scale — with help from initiatives such as CNCA and C40.

Why bio-based materials?

Using bio-based materials — organic resources produced by plants and animals, such as timber or sheep’s wool — is considered one of the most effective routes to not only decarbonising the built environment, but shifting to a more regenerative future. Apart from offering low-embodied carbon alternatives to conventional construction materials, bio-based materials are renewable and can be sustainably produced. They provide a number of additional co-benefits including faster, safer and cleaner construction; easier and more sustainable reuse or composting options at end of life; healthier internal environments; and a boost to rural economies — something of particular relevance at a time where we’re seeing a growing urban-rural political divide, especially with regard to the environment.

Why material circularity?

The built environment is responsible for nearly 40% of global material extraction. Whilst construction and demolition waste (CDW) accounts for a third of total waste generated in the EU. This linear material extraction, use and disposal paradigm represents a material economy and a way of interacting with the natural world that is no longer viable at a planetary scale. The need to transition to a more circular model is increasingly urgent.

As former president of the American Institute of Architects, Carl Elefante, famously said, the greenest, most sustainable building is the one that already exists. While the scope of HCC EU CINCO mostly focuses on supporting decarbonisation in new construction, we recognise this needs to happen within a ‘building circularity hierarchy’.

Circular economy for the built environment (LETI, 2022)

This framework prioritises increasing the utilisation and prolonging the life of existing buildings through maintenance; above refurbishing, repurposing, and deconstructing them for reuse; and finally remanufacturing, reprocessing and recycling components. While this blog series will not go into detail on these aspects, we acknowledge their critical importance.

Project partners

The project has involved a consortium comprising EIT Climate-KIC, Democratic Society, Material Economics, Bankers without Boundaries, and Dark Matter Labs, working in close collaboration with local partners in the two focus cities. In Madrid, these include UPM, Arup, Madrid City Council and CreaMNN. In Milan, the partnership has involved POLIMI, AMAT and Redo. Our work related to digital tool development and spatial data prototyping has been supported by our close partners, The Center for Spatial Technologies.

Testbed sites Architectural renders of Milan L’Innesto (Left) and Madrid Nuevo Norte (Right)

Two sites were selected to test in practice the innovations proposed as part of the project (more on these innovations below). The two testbeds — sites for conducting rigorous, transparent and replicable testing — are two of Europe’s largest urban regeneration projects: Madrid Nuevo Norte (MNN) and Milan’s L’Innesto. MNN is a large-scale development with high sustainability aspirations which seeks to integrate Chamartín Rail Station with the rest of the city. Whilst L’Innesto aims to be Italy’s first carbon-neutral social housing development, located at Scalo Greco Breda, a former freight terminal site.

By working closely with the project teams of these test sites, alongside local partners from academia, municipal government, private sector and civic organisations, the consortium has had access to a wealth of knowledge and perspectives. This has made it possible to ground the project in real world contexts, deeply understand structural and specific challenges and opportunities from the viewpoint of the diverse stakeholders, and work together to overcome barriers collaboratively.

Approach

As part of our work, we’ve adopted a whole-systems approach to understand the blocks and bottlenecks that limit the uptake of low embodied carbon materials and circular construction practices, as well as to identify opportunities to accelerate their uptake. This means we have tried to look at the whole picture to understand how regulation, procurement and contracting, material and construction data, digital capacities, finance, culture, habits and ways of working all come together to influence the decision-making of stakeholders along the process — from forestry agents, bio-based material manufacturers, designers, construction teams and academic researchers to policy makers, municipal officials, legislators, insurers, developers and building users.

We’ve worked collaboratively to strengthen our collective understanding of barriers and opportunities while fostering network building, connection and communication across actors. We believe that the entangled complexity, scale and urgency of the challenges we face, necessitates the whole ecosystem working together to drive the transition to a regenerative, low carbon and circular built environment.

Over the past two years we’ve worked closely with local partners using four strategies:

Building contextual and technical knowledge through interviews and secondary research which we then share via reports and/or sensemaking sessions Fostering connections through participatory processes such as collaborative workshops and communication events Designing solutions to current key challenges in close collaboration with “problem owners”, those with the means and mandate to tackle the issue and those who most feel its impact Sharing provocations to invite partners to think beyond what is possible today to what is necessary in the long term Focus areas

These strategies have been implemented through a series of interconnected interventions as part of a portfolio, which was co-defined with partners and spans multiple levers:

Finance; Policy and regulation; Contracting and procurement; Digital tools and data; Capacity and capability building; Networks and shared narrative HCC: EU CINCO focused on six strategic levers (DML focused on the blue layers)

Over the course of the first phase of the initiative, Dark Matter Labs has focused on three of these interlinking levers of change — Policy and regulation; Contracting and procurement; and Digital tools and data. We’ve also developed transversal activities focusing on Capacity and capability building and conducted a study analysing the economic and environmental impact of using sustainable timber in the Madrid testbed. Each of these will be covered in more detail in a subsequent post.

Overview of activities

The project has involved us conducting over 30 interviews with actors along the timber value chain and compiling their diverse perspectives on challenges and opportunities in a shared document. While it helped uncover indispensable and detailed contextual knowledge, it also fostered a shared understanding to help disparate stakeholders work together and see their interconnections and potential synergies more easily. We also conducted in depth research and compiled briefing documents on Digital tools and data; and Policy, regulation and contractual innovation in relation to low embodied carbon and circular construction in Madrid and Milan.

Project outputs: Timber value chain learnings; Digital tools & data brief; Policy & regulation brief

Additionally we hosted collaborative work sessions with select experts — from the fields of energy, architecture, urbanism and ecology — as part of an innovative process for proposing regulatory changes to integrate carbon and climate conscious perspectives in the review of urban planning legislation in Madrid and to suggest a new approach for learning-focused regulatory sandboxes.

Project outputs: WLC reporting template; Municipal price list provocation

As to concrete solutions to the barriers currently faced by our local partners, it has led us to design clauses to require whole life carbon assessment in the tender processes of Madrid Nuevo Norte; to develop easy to use templates to compile embodied carbon data; and to propose new, low carbon and bio-based materials to be included in Madrid’s municipal list of prices (Cuadro de Precios) — a public list of prices for materials, products and construction processes for use in preparing a bill of quantities for public construction projects.

Recognising the need to work at two speeds — tackling current problems and implementing actions that are feasible today, while considering the long term and working to expand the boundaries of our own and our partner’s imaginations as to what is possible — we have also developed a number of “provocations”. These are thought pieces co-exploring what we think may be needed; meant to inspire, invite discussion and foster new courses of action. As part of this line of work, we reimagined what a climate conscious 21st century municipal price list could be, and developed a proof of concept for a material registry — MatR: An open source, web-based digital tool that aggregates data on what buildings are made of and how well they perform, which could enable more holistic decisions to minimise life cycle environmental impacts and maximise material circularity in the built environment.

Project outputs: Economic analysis of increased forestry in Castilla-La Mancha; MatR — A digital registry for a building’s material and performance data.

As part of the project, we also conducted a regional economic and environmental impact analysis to illustrate the potential impact of increased demand for engineered timber products on the local forestry industry and its related activities within the region of Castilla-La Mancha, Spain.

These will be discussed in more detail in subsequent posts.

Strategic learning

Through working across multiple levers of change, we identified three necessary shifts to make the transition to low carbon, bio-based, circular construction possible:

Re-defining cost and value: From a short term and narrow conception focused on direct cost and profit; to a long term and broad conception that considers wider economic, environmental and social impacts and how they are inherently linked. Re-thinking collaboration: From centralised and siloed approaches where design, manufacture, construction and maintenance are considered independently, and there’s limited stakeholder collaboration; to distributed and multi-actor ways of working where shared responsibility frameworks support innovation and institutional infrastructure facilitates learning and cooperation. Re-scoping focus: From sector specific approaches in which single point interventions can lead to uncoordinated and sometimes conflicting results; to systemic​ approaches in which multiple levers (finance, regulation, etc.), diverse domains (energy, biodiversity, health, etc.), and their interactions are considered together to minimise negative externalities and maximise co-benefits. A multi-lever approach for a low carbon, circular and just built environment

Collectively, the range of experiments we initiated with our partners aim to help make these necessary shifts possible. Alongside these, a number of key lessons have also emerged:

1 — We have found that barriers are often related to capacity, capabilities and political and normative choices, rather than to technological limitations.

Barriers often arise from individuals or organisations having limited time or resources to do things differently, lacking the means to innovate or having limited access to knowledge. Often barriers arise in decision making processes where economic, political and climate values are perceived as contradictory or conflicting. Therefore, focusing on strengthening the capacities and capabilities of key stakeholders to enable collaborative learning; embracing agile action; and long term thinking, becomes critical. This led us to directing more efforts than initially planned to support essential capability building amongst key actors, including municipal officials, and relevant construction sector and industry players.

2 — We’ve witnessed the need for new approaches to planning, financing and agile collaboration.

Different stakeholders are subject to very different paces and timeframes. Political cycles, fiscal years and university research timelines don’t usually coincide, complicating multi-actor collaboration and project financing.

At the same time, because of the ongoing interaction between all the different parts of the system and the continuous evolution of internal and external pressures, traditional linear planning is unable to respond with the necessary flexibility and learning focus to complex challenges such as that of decarbonising construction. This has prompted us to search for and test new ways to plan, fund and collaborate.

3 — We’ve experienced how difficult deep collaboration is. Strategic cross collaboration has to be designed explicitly from the start.

For many of us, working collaboratively with very different partners isn’t the usual mode of operation. It may require more time to reach mutual understanding and build trust. When faced with tight deadlines and workload pressure, we may be tempted to retreat to working individually and in silos instead of collaborating across domains. However, together we’re able to achieve better quality, more impactful results. To make this possible, we found collaboration had to be established as a shared objective early on. Time for collective sense-making whilst working individually is not enough; working together through shared challenges accelerates mutual understanding and facilitates deeper collaboration. Deadlines, budget and expectations need to be adjusted accordingly. In response to these insights, we are working to integrate this approach more fully in the next stage of our work.

In order to respond to continuously evolving contexts, it is also critical to continue to build our capability to be agile and recognise when it’s time to shift focus and adapt resource allocation quickly. This also entails building our decision making capacity so that we’re able to commit the time and resources necessary for exploring areas of potential deeply, without being distracted by emerging opportunities with less potential.

Additionally, local partner collaboration is invaluable. However, navigating complexity and uncertainty in a second language is difficult. Local partners don’t always feel comfortable or are not able to engage deeply in English. Therefore, deep collaboration with local partners requires speaking the local language.

4 —Within the wider context, we recognise how far cities still have to go to engage deeply with this planet-critical challenge.

As the latest IPCC report starkly warns, “there is a rapidly closing window of opportunity to secure a liveable and sustainable future for all” and an urgent need for “deep, rapid and sustained mitigation and accelerated implementation of adaptation actions in this decade [to] reduce projected losses and damages for humans and ecosystems.” There remain significant gaps between the projected emissions from implemented policies and those from nationally determined contributions (NDCs) — on our current trajectory, it’s likely that warming will exceed 1.5°C in the 21st century and will be hard to limit below 2°C.

This gives a clear indication of the scale and urgency of transition required across Europe and beyond, to deliver on our collective climate ambitions. Cities must play their part by accelerating the impact of mitigation and adaptation measures, whilst sharing lessons across sectors and borders. In the built environment in particular, there remains a large disconnect between what is needed in response to the climate crisis and what is currently being built or planned in terms of new development. Collaborative city networks, for example C40 and CNCA, provide the scaffold for mobilising transformative climate action, disseminating best practice and accelerating change in municipal policy and action. Yet, decision making still does not respond to the depth and urgency of required action.

We also acknowledge this is particularly hard in the built environment and construction sector, where in some contexts a significant portion of GDP is linked to carbon and material intensive practices. As a sector, it’s typically slow to change and comes with significant risks in terms of job losses and industry phase-out. Here, carefully designed policies along with targeted public investment will be necessary to ensure a just and inclusive transition.

In conclusion, this work has shown us some of the challenges of attempting to work systemically while operating within structures and systems that have been set up with predefined objectives, and sector specific or siloed approaches which are no longer fit for purpose.

We recognise that, within the project scope, we’re still working out how to overcome these barriers and will continue to test new ways of working collaboratively, through exploration, while navigating an ever evolving context in which new needs and opportunities will continue to emerge. Sharing our learning and reflections thus becomes mission critical. We hope you will join us on this journey.

Other posts in this series

This is part of a series covering work we’ve been doing to support efforts to decarbonise construction and transition to more circular construction practices. Follow the links below to access the other posts:

Part 1: Overview — Towards a post-carbon built environment Part 2: Data’s role for a post-carbon built environment Part 3: Decarbonising through policy, regulation and procurement (coming soon) Part 4: Towards a sustainable timber value chain in Spain (coming soon)

Towards a post-carbon built environment was originally published in Dark Matter Laboratories on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
